Taichi language

Decouple data structure from computation.
stencil
Spatial sparsity is specially treated in taichi. Different data structures can be used to process this sparsity in the compiler.
Single program multiple data (SPMD)
Data structure: array of structure(AOS) & structure of array(SOA)

Taichi syntax basics

The gene of Taichi is parallel computing.

Data format

Tensor is a multidim array whose elements can be everything even matrices.

import taichi as ti
ti.init()

a = ti.var(dt=ti.f32, shape=(42,63)) # a tensor of 42X63 scalars
b = ti.Vector(3, dt=ti.f32, shape=4) # a tensor of 4X3D vectors
c = ti.Matrix(2,2,dt=ti.f32,shape=(3,5)) # a tensor of 3X5 2X2 matrices
# ti.* defines the type of each element and the first part defines the size of each element
loss = ti.var(dt=ti.f32, shape=()) # this is a scalar defined in tensor form
loss[None]=3 # use this to assign value to a scalar in a tensor form

Kernel and function

In Taichi, kernel is the computation function.
Kernels must be decorated with @ti.kernel. They can call functions but cannot be call other kernels.
Taichi functions can be called directly by Taichi kernels and other Taichi functions but not python. Only one return is supported up to now. They must be decorated with @ti.func.

Element-wise product *; marix product @.

For loops

For loops in Taichi have 2 forms.

  • Range-for loops: Similar to Python. Will be parallelized when used at the outermost scope.
  • Struct-for loops: Iterates over (sparse) tensor elements.
    For loops at the outermost scope in Taichi is automatically parallelized.
ti.init(arch=ti.gpu)
n = 320
pixels = ti.var(dt=ti.f32, shape=(2*n, n))
@ti.kernel
def paint(t:ti.f32):
    for i,j in pixels:
        pixels[i,j] = i*3+j*4+t

Atomic operations

Atomic operation is designed to deal with parallel computing. An atomic operation will go from start to finish without interruption of other threads.
In Taichi, augmented assignments (x[i]+=1)

a[None] += 1 [right]
ti.atomic_add(a[None], 1) [right]
a[None] = a[None] + 1 [wrong]

Scope

Taichi-scope: in @ti.kernel or @ti.func. Compiled in Taichi and run in parallel.

Python-scope: Compiled in Python.

Phases of a Taichi program

  • Initialization: ti.init(‚Ä¶)
  • Tensor allocation: ti.var, ti.Vector, ti.Matrix
  • Computation (lauch kernels‚Ä¶)
  • Optional: restart the Taichi system (clear memory, destroy variables and kernels‚Ä¶) ti.reset()

‚ùïüëÄ After the first ti.kernel, no more tensor allocation is allowed.

# fractal.py
import taichi as ti
ti.init(arch=ti.cpu)

n=320
pixels = ti.var(dt=ti.f32, shape=(2*n, n))

@ti.func
def complex_sqr(z):
    return ti.Vector([z[0]**2 - z[1]**2, z[1] * z[0] *2])

@ti.kernel
def paint(t: ti.f32):
    for i,j in pixels:
        c = ti.Vector([-0.8, ti.cos(t) * 0.2])
        z = ti.Vector([i/n - 1, j/n - 0.5]) * 2
        iterations = 0
        while z.norm() < 20 and iterations < 50:
            z = complex_sqr(z) + c
            iterations += 1
        pixels[i, j] = 1 - iterations * 0.02

gui = ti.GUI("Julia Set", res=(n * 2, n))
for i in range(1000000):
    paint(i * 0.03)
    gui.set_image(pixels)
    gui.show()

Debug mode

debug = True (cpu only)

ti.init(debug=True, arch=ti.cpu)
a = ti.var(dt=ti.f32, shape=(10))
b = ti.var(dt=ti.f32, shape=(10))
@ti.kernel
def shift():
    for i in range(10):
        a[i] = b[i+1]
# bound checker is only activated in debug mode to save time in normal mode.
shift()

Lagrangian and Eulerian View

Lagrangian view: move with object.

Eulerian view: static.

Lagrangian simulation approaches (1)

Mass-spring system

fij=‚àík(‚à•xi‚àíxj‚à•2‚àílij)(xi‚àíxj^)(Hooke‚Ä≤s‚Äâlaw)fi=‚àëjj‚â†ifij‚àÇvi‚àÇt=1mifi(Newton‚Ä≤s‚Äâsecond‚Äâlaw‚Äâof‚Äâmotion)‚àÇxi‚àÇt=vi\begin{aligned} \mathbf{f}{ij}&=-k(\|\mathbf{x}_i-\mathbf{x}_j\|_2-l_{ij})(\widehat{\mathbf{x}_i-\mathbf{x}_j})\quad(\rm Hooke's\,law)\\ \mathbf{f}_i&=\sum_j^{j\neq i}\mathbf{f}_{ij}\\ \frac{\partial \mathbf{v}_i}{\partial t}&=\frac{1}{m_i}\mathbf{f}_i\quad(\rm Newton's\,second\,law\,of\,motion)\\ \frac{\partial \mathbf{x}_i}{\partial t}&=\mathbf{v}_i\\ \end{aligned}fijfi‚Äã‚àÇt‚àÇvi‚Äã‚Äã‚àÇt‚àÇxi‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã=‚àík(‚à•xi‚Äã‚àíxj‚Äã‚à•2‚Äã‚àílij‚Äã)(xi‚Äã‚àíxj‚Äã‚Äã)(Hooke‚Ä≤slaw)=j‚àëjÓÄ†‚Äã=i‚Äãfij‚Äã=mi‚Äã1‚Äãfi‚Äã(Newton‚Ä≤ssecondlawofmotion)=vi‚Äã‚Äã

xi‚àíxj^\widehat{\mathbf{x}_i-\mathbf{x}_j}xi‚Äã‚àíxj‚Äã‚Äã: direction vector from particle iii to particle jjj (unit vector).
‚ñ°^\widehat{\Box}‚ñ° means normalization.

Implicit time integration:

with taylor expansion


To solver this linear system, there are many methods like Jacobi iteration/Gauss-Seidel iteration or conjugate gradients(ÂÖ±ËΩ≠Ê¢ØÂ∫¶), etc.
Unifying explict and implicit:

Solve faster
For system with millions of mass points and springs,

  • Sparse matrices
  • Conjugate gradients
  • Preconditioning
  • Use position-based dynamics(PBD)
  • Also some faster approches like Fast mass-spring system solver(‚ÄúFast simulation of mass-spring systems‚Äù in ACM Transactions)

Time integration

1Ô∏è‚É£ Forward Euler (explicit)
vt+1=vt+Œîtftmxt+1=xt+Œîtvt\begin{aligned} \mathbf{v}_{t+1}&=\mathbf{v}_t+\Delta t\frac{\mathbf{f}_t}{m}\\ \mathbf{x}_{t+1}&=\mathbf{x}_t+\Delta t\mathbf{v}_t\\ \end{aligned}vt+1‚Äãxt+1‚Äã‚Äã=vt‚Äã+Œîtmft‚Äã‚Äã=xt‚Äã+Œîtvt‚Äã‚Äã

2Ô∏è‚É£ Semi implicit Euler (aka. symplectic Euler, explicit)
vt+1=vt+Œîtftmxt+1=xt+Œîtvt+1\begin{aligned} \mathbf{v}_{t+1}&=\mathbf{v}_t+\Delta t\frac{\mathbf{f}_t}{m}\\ \mathbf{x}_{t+1}&=\mathbf{x}_t+\Delta t\mathbf{v}_{t+1}\\ \end{aligned}vt+1‚Äãxt+1‚Äã‚Äã=vt‚Äã+Œîtmft‚Äã‚Äã=xt‚Äã+Œîtvt+1‚Äã‚Äã

3Ô∏è‚É£ Backward Euler (often with Newton‚Äôs method, implicit)

Explicit v.s. implicit time integration

Explicit (forward Euler, symplectic Euler, RK, ‚Ä¶)
Œît‚â§cmkc‚âà1\Delta t \leq c\sqrt{\frac{m}{k}} \quad c\approx1Œît‚â§ckm‚Äã‚Äãc‚âà1

Lagrangian simulation approaches (2)

Basics of deformation, elasticity and FEM

Deformation
Deformation map œï\phiœï:xdeformed=œï(xrest)\mathbf{x}_{\rm deformed}=\phi(\mathbf{x}_{\rm rest})xdeformed‚Äã=œï(xrest‚Äã)

This relates rest material position with deformed material position.

Deformation gradient F\mathbf{F}F:F:=‚àÇxdeformed‚àÇxrest\mathbf{F}:=\frac{\partial\mathbf{x}_{\rm deformed}}{\partial\mathbf{x}_{\rm rest}}F:=‚àÇxrest‚Äã‚àÇxdeformed‚Äã‚Äã

Deformation gradients are translational invariant.
œï1=œï(xrest)\phi_1=\phi(\mathbf{x}_{\rm rest})œï1‚Äã=œï(xrest‚Äã) and œï2=œï(xrest)+c\phi_2=\phi(\mathbf{x}_{\rm rest})+\rm cœï2‚Äã=œï(xrest‚Äã)+c have the same F\mathbf{F}F.

Deform/rest volume ratio J=det‚Å°(F)J=\det(\mathbf{F})J=det(F)

Elasticity
Hyperelasticity
whose stress-strain relationship is defined by strain energy density function.
œà=œà(F)\psi=\psi(\mathbf{F})œà=œà(F)

There are different measures of stress:

  • THe First Piola-Kirchhoff stress tensor (PK1):P(F)=‚àÇœà(F)‚àÇF\mathbf{P}(\mathbf{F})=\frac{\partial\psi(\mathbf{F})}{\partial\mathbf{F}}P(F)=‚àÇF‚àÇœà(F)‚Äã (easy to compute but in rest space)
  • Kirchhoff stress: œÑ\boldsymbol{\tau}œÑ
  • Cauchy stress tensor: œÉ\boldsymbol{\sigma}œÉ (symmetric)

Relationship: œÑ=JœÉ=PFTP=JœÉF‚àíTTraction‚Äât=œÉTn\boldsymbol{\tau}=J\boldsymbol{\sigma}=\mathbf{P}\mathbf{F}^T\quad\mathbf{P}=J\boldsymbol{\sigma}\mathbf{F}^{-T}\quad \rm Traction\,\mathbf{t}=\boldsymbol{\sigma}^T\boldsymbol{n}œÑ=JœÉ=PFTP=JœÉF‚àíTTractiont=œÉTn

  • Young‚Äôs modulus E=œÉŒµE = \frac{\sigma}{\varepsilon}E=ŒµœÉ‚Äã
  • Bulk modulus K=‚àíVdPdVK = -V\frac{dP}{dV}K=‚àíVdVdP‚Äã
  • Poisson‚Äôs ratio ŒΩ‚àà[0,0.5)\nu\in[0,0.5)ŒΩ‚àà[0,0.5)
  • Lame‚Äôs first parameter Œº\muŒº; Lame‚Äôs second parameter Œª\lambdaŒª (aka. shear modulus GGG)

conversion formula:
K=E3(1‚àí2ŒΩ)Œª=EŒΩ(1+ŒΩ)(1‚àí2ŒΩ)Œº=E2(1+ŒΩ)K=\frac{E}{3(1-2\nu)}\qquad\lambda=\frac{E\nu}{(1+\nu)(1-2\nu)}\qquad\mu=\frac{E}{2(1+\nu)}K=3(1‚àí2ŒΩ)E‚ÄãŒª=(1+ŒΩ)(1‚àí2ŒΩ)EŒΩ‚ÄãŒº=2(1+ŒΩ)E‚Äã

Popular hyperelastic material models (for each element)

  • Neo-Hookean
    • œà(F)=Œº2‚àëi[(FTF)ii‚àí1]‚àíŒºlog‚Å°(J)+Œª2log‚Å°2(J)\psi(\mathbf{F})=\frac{\mu}{2}\sum_i[(\mathbf{F}^T\mathbf{F})_{ii}-1]-\mu\log(J)+\frac{\lambda}{2}\log^2(J)œà(F)=2Œº‚Äã‚àëi‚Äã[(FTF)ii‚Äã‚àí1]‚àíŒºlog(J)+2Œª‚Äãlog2(J)
    • P(F)=‚àÇœà(F)‚àÇF=Œº(F‚àíF‚àíT)+Œªlog‚Å°(J)F‚àíT\mathbf{P}(\mathbf{F})=\frac{\partial\psi(\mathbf{F})}{\partial\mathbf{F}}=\mu(\mathbf{F}-\mathbf{F}^{-T})+\lambda\log(J)\mathbf{F}^{-T}P(F)=‚àÇF‚àÇœà(F)‚Äã=Œº(F‚àíF‚àíT)+Œªlog(J)F‚àíT
  • (Fixed) Corotated
    • œà(F)=Œº‚àëi(œÉi‚àí1)2+Œª2(J‚àí1)2\psi(\mathbf{F})=\mu\sum_i(\mathbf{\sigma}_i-1)^2+\frac{\lambda}{2}(J-1)^2œà(F)=Œº‚àëi‚Äã(œÉi‚Äã‚àí1)2+2Œª‚Äã(J‚àí1)2
    • P(F)=‚àÇœà‚àÇF=2Œº(F‚àíR)+Œª(J‚àí1)JF‚àíT\mathbf{P}(\mathbf{F})=\frac{\partial \psi}{\partial \mathbf{F}}=2\mu(\mathbf{F}-\mathbf{R})+\lambda(J-1)J\mathbf{F}^{-T}P(F)=‚àÇF‚àÇœà‚Äã=2Œº(F‚àíR)+Œª(J‚àí1)JF‚àíT

FEM
Linear tetrahedral FEM
The deformation map œï\phiœï is affine and thus deformation gradient F\mathbf{F}F is constant within a single tetrahedral element:
xdeformed=Fxrest+b\rm \mathbf{x}_{deformed}=\mathbf{F}\mathbf{x}_{rest}+\mathbf{b}xdeformed‚Äã=Fxrest‚Äã+b

For every element eee, its elastic potential energy
U(e)=‚à´eœà(F(x))x=Veœà(Fe)U(e)=\int_e\psi(\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{x}))\mathbf{x}=V_e\psi(\mathbf{F}_e)U(e)=‚à´e‚Äãœà(F(x))x=Ve‚Äãœà(Fe‚Äã)

For explicit scheme (semi-implicit)
vt+1,i=vt,i+Œîtft,imi\mathbf{v}_{t+1,i}=\mathbf{v}_{t,i}+\Delta t\frac{\mathbf{f}_{t,i}}{m_i}vt+1,i‚Äã=vt,i‚Äã+Œîtmi‚Äãft,i‚Äã‚Äã

xt+1,i=xt,i+Œîtvt+1,i\mathbf{x}_{t+1,i}=\mathbf{x}_{t,i}+\Delta t\mathbf{v}_{t+1,i}xt+1,i‚Äã=xt,i‚Äã+Œîtvt+1,i‚Äã

ft,i‚â°‚àí‚àÇU‚àÇxi=‚àí‚àëe‚àÇU(e)‚àÇxi=‚àí‚àëeVe‚àÇœà(Fe)‚àÇFe‚àÇFe‚àÇxi=‚àí‚àëeVeP(Fe)‚àÇFe‚àÇxi\mathbf{f}_{t,i}\equiv-\frac{\partial U}{\partial \mathbf{x}_i}=-\sum_e\frac{\partial U(e)}{\partial \mathbf{x}_i}=-\sum_e V_e\frac{\partial\psi(\mathbf{F}_e)}{\partial\mathbf{F}_e}\frac{\partial \mathbf{F}_e}{\partial \mathbf{x}_i}=-\sum_eV_e\mathbf{P}(\mathbf{F}_e)\frac{\partial\mathbf{F}_e}{\partial\mathbf{x}_i}ft,i‚Äã‚â°‚àí‚àÇxi‚Äã‚àÇU‚Äã=‚àíe‚àë‚Äã‚àÇxi‚Äã‚àÇU(e)‚Äã=‚àíe‚àë‚ÄãVe‚Äã‚àÇFe‚Äã‚àÇœà(Fe‚Äã)‚Äã‚àÇxi‚Äã‚àÇFe‚Äã‚Äã=‚àíe‚àë‚ÄãVe‚ÄãP(Fe‚Äã)‚àÇxi‚Äã‚àÇFe‚Äã‚Äã

Taichi programming language advanced features

ODOP

Data-oriented programming (DOP)
Objective data-oriented programming (ODOP)

  • 3 important decorators
    • Use @ti.data_oriented to decorate class.
    • Use @ti.kernel to decorate class members functions that are Taichi kernels.
    • Use @ti.func to decorate class members functions that are Taichi functions.
Metaprogramming
  • Allow to pass almost anything to Taichi kernels
  • Improve run-time performance by moving run-time costs to compile time
  • Achieve dimensionality independence
  • Simplify the development of Taichi standard library
@ti.kernel
def copy(x: ti.template(), y: ti.template(), c: ti.f32):
    for i in x:
        y[i] = x[i] + c

Variable aliasing

Differentiable programming

reverse-mode automatic differentiation (AutoDiff)
f(x)‚áí‚àÇf(x)‚àÇxf(x)\Rightarrow\frac{\partial f(x)}{\partial x}f(x)‚áí‚àÇx‚àÇf(x)‚Äã

Eulerian Fluid Simulation

Gradient

Ê¢ØÂ∫¶
Hamilton operator ‚àá=(‚àÇ‚àÇx1,‚àÇ‚àÇx2,‚Ä¶,‚àÇ‚àÇxn)\nabla=(\frac{\partial}{\partial x_1},\frac{\partial}{\partial x_2},\dots,\frac{\partial}{\partial x_n})‚àá=(‚àÇx1‚Äã‚àÇ‚Äã,‚àÇx2‚Äã‚àÇ‚Äã,‚Ä¶,‚àÇxn‚Äã‚àÇ‚Äã)

Linear FEM and Topology optimization

FEM overview

It belongs to the family of Galerkin methods.

  • Convert strong (accurate at every point) to weak form
  • Integrate by parts
  • Use divergence theorem to simplify equations and enforce Neumann boundary conditions
  • Discretization (build stiffness matrix and right-hand side)
  • Solve the linear system

Discretizing Poisson‚Äôs equation

2D Poisson‚Äôs equation

‚àá‚ãÖ‚àáu=0\nabla\cdot\nabla u=0‚àá‚ãÖ‚àáu=0

Dirichlet boundary: displacement(Á¨¨‰∏ÄÁ±ªËæπÁïåÊù°‰ª∂)
u(x)=f(x)u(x)=f(x)u(x)=f(x)
Neumann boundary: some kind of force(Á¨¨‰∫åÁ±ªËæπÁïåÊù°‰ª∂)
‚àáu(x)‚ãÖn=g(x)\nabla u(x)\cdot \boldsymbol{n}=g(x)‚àáu(x)‚ãÖn=g(x)

Weak formulation

Arbitrary 2D test function w(x)w(x)w(x):
‚àá‚ãÖ‚àáu=0‚áî‚àÄw,‚à¨Œ©w(‚àá‚ãÖ‚àáu)dA=0\nabla\cdot\nabla u=0 \Leftrightarrow \forall w,\iint_\Omega w(\nabla\cdot\nabla u)dA=0‚àá‚ãÖ‚àáu=0‚áî‚àÄw,‚à¨Œ©‚Äãw(‚àá‚ãÖ‚àáu)dA=0

Getting rid of second-order terms

We want to get rid of ‚àá‚ãÖ‚àá\nabla\cdot\nabla‚àá‚ãÖ‚àá in ‚àá‚ãÖ‚àáu=0\nabla\cdot\nabla u=0‚àá‚ãÖ‚àáu=0.
Integrate by parts:
‚àáw‚ãÖ‚àáu+w‚àá‚ãÖ‚àáu=‚àá‚ãÖ(w‚àáu)\nabla w\cdot\nabla u+w\nabla\cdot\nabla u=\nabla\cdot(w\nabla u)‚àáw‚ãÖ‚àáu+w‚àá‚ãÖ‚àáu=‚àá‚ãÖ(w‚àáu)
Since ‚àá‚ãÖ‚àáu=0\nabla\cdot\nabla u=0‚àá‚ãÖ‚àáu=0, we have
‚àáw‚ãÖ‚àáu=‚àá‚ãÖ(w‚àáu)\nabla w\cdot\nabla u=\nabla\cdot(w\nabla u)‚àáw‚ãÖ‚àáu=‚àá‚ãÖ(w‚àáu)
Thus we have
‚àá‚ãÖ‚àáu=0‚áî‚àÄw,‚à¨Œ©‚àáw‚ãÖ‚àáu‚ÄâdA=‚à¨Œ©‚àá‚ãÖ(w‚àáu)dA\nabla\cdot\nabla u=0 \Leftrightarrow \forall w, \iint_\Omega\nabla w\cdot \nabla u\, dA=\iint_\Omega\nabla\cdot(w\nabla u)dA‚àá‚ãÖ‚àáu=0‚áî‚àÄw,‚à¨Œ©‚Äã‚àáw‚ãÖ‚àáudA=‚à¨Œ©‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖ(w‚àáu)dA.
Apply divergence theorem to RHS(right-hand side)
‚à¨Œ©‚àáw‚ãÖ‚àáu‚ÄâdA=‚àÆ‚àÇŒ©w‚àáu‚ãÖdn\iint_\Omega\nabla w\cdot \nabla u\, dA=\oint_{\partial \Omega} w\nabla u\cdot d\boldsymbol{n}‚à¨Œ©‚Äã‚àáw‚ãÖ‚àáudA=‚àÆ‚àÇŒ©‚Äãw‚àáu‚ãÖdn

Discretization

We represent u(x)u(x)u(x) as
u(x)=‚àëjujœïj(x)u(x)=\sum_j u_j \phi_j(x)u(x)=‚àëj‚Äãuj‚Äãœïj‚Äã(x)
Substitute this into the former equation
‚àÄw,‚à¨Œ©‚àáw‚ãÖ‚àá(‚àëjujœïj)‚ÄâdA=‚àÆ‚àÇŒ©w‚àáu‚ãÖdn\forall w, \iint_\Omega\nabla w\cdot \nabla (\sum_j u_j \phi_j)\, dA=\oint_{\partial \Omega} w\nabla u\cdot d\boldsymbol{n}‚àÄw,‚à¨Œ©‚Äã‚àáw‚ãÖ‚àá(‚àëj‚Äãuj‚Äãœïj‚Äã)dA=‚àÆ‚àÇŒ©‚Äãw‚àáu‚ãÖdn
We also use basis function œïi\phi_iœïi‚Äã as the test function www, and we have
‚àÄi,‚à¨Œ©‚àáœïi‚ãÖ‚àá(‚àëjujœïj)‚ÄâdA=‚àÆ‚àÇŒ©œïi‚àáu‚ãÖdn\forall i, \iint_\Omega\nabla \phi_i\cdot \nabla (\sum_j u_j \phi_j)\, dA=\oint_{\partial \Omega} \phi_i\nabla u\cdot d\boldsymbol{n}‚àÄi,‚à¨Œ©‚Äã‚àáœïi‚Äã‚ãÖ‚àá(‚àëj‚Äãuj‚Äãœïj‚Äã)dA=‚àÆ‚àÇŒ©‚Äãœïi‚Äã‚àáu‚ãÖdn
Extract ‚àëjuj\sum_j u_j‚àëj‚Äãuj‚Äã out of ‚à¨\iint‚à¨
‚àÄi,‚àëj(‚à¨Œ©‚àáœïi‚ãÖ‚àáœïj‚ÄâdA)uj=‚àÆ‚àÇŒ©œïi‚àáu‚ãÖdn\forall i, \sum_j(\iint_\Omega\nabla \phi_i\cdot \nabla \phi_j\, dA)u_j=\oint_{\partial \Omega} \phi_i\nabla u\cdot d\boldsymbol{n}‚àÄi,‚àëj‚Äã(‚à¨Œ©‚Äã‚àáœïi‚Äã‚ãÖ‚àáœïj‚ÄãdA)uj‚Äã=‚àÆ‚àÇŒ©‚Äãœïi‚Äã‚àáu‚ãÖdn
In matrix form
Ku=f\boldsymbol{Ku=f}Ku=f

  • Dirichlet BCs u(x)=f(x),x‚àà‚àÇŒ©u(x)=f(x), x\in \partial\Omegau(x)=f(x),x‚àà‚àÇŒ©:
    set ui=f(xi)u_i=f(x_i)ui‚Äã=f(xi‚Äã)
  • Neumann BCs ‚àáu(x)‚ãÖn=g(x),x‚àà‚àÇŒ©\nabla u(x)\cdot\boldsymbol{n}=g(x),x\in\partial\Omega‚àáu(x)‚ãÖn=g(x),x‚àà‚àÇŒ©:
    Plug g into the RHS of the equation, which yields non-zeros in f\boldsymbol{f}f. (Some kind of force)

Discretizing linear elasticity

Linear elasticity FEM

Cauchy momentum equation
DvDt=1œÅ‚àá‚ãÖœÉ+g\frac{Dv}{Dt}=\frac{1}{\rho}\nabla\cdot\sigma+gDtDv‚Äã=œÅ1‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖœÉ+g

œÅ\rhoœÅ: density
œÉ\sigmaœÉ: cauchy stress tensor

For quasi-static state(v=0v=0v=0), constant density, no gravity:
‚àá‚ãÖœÉ=0\nabla\cdot\sigma=0‚àá‚ãÖœÉ=0

Index notation

DvDt=1œÅ‚àá‚ãÖœÉ+g‚áîDvŒ±Dt=1œÅ‚àëŒ≤œÉŒ±Œ≤,Œ≤+gŒ±\frac{Dv}{Dt}=\frac{1}{\rho}\nabla\cdot\sigma+g \Leftrightarrow \frac{Dv_\alpha}{Dt}=\frac{1}{\rho}\sum_\beta \sigma_{\alpha\beta,\beta}+g_\alphaDtDv‚Äã=œÅ1‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖœÉ+g‚áîDtDvŒ±‚Äã‚Äã=œÅ1‚Äã‚àëŒ≤‚ÄãœÉŒ±Œ≤,Œ≤‚Äã+gŒ±‚Äã

Discretize Cauchy momentum equation using FEM

‚àÄŒ±‚àÄi,‚à¨Œ©‚àëŒ≤[œÉ(u(x))]Œ±Œ≤œïiŒ±(x)dA=‚àÆ‚àÇŒ©‚àëŒ≤(œÉŒ±Œ≤œïiŒ±dnŒ≤)\forall\alpha\forall i, \iint_\Omega\sum_\beta[\sigma(u(x))]_{\alpha\beta}\phi_{i\alpha}(x)dA=\oint_{\partial\Omega}\sum_\beta(\sigma_{\alpha\beta}\phi_{i\alpha}dn_\beta)‚àÄŒ±‚àÄi,‚à¨Œ©‚Äã‚àëŒ≤‚Äã[œÉ(u(x))]Œ±Œ≤‚ÄãœïiŒ±‚Äã(x)dA=‚àÆ‚àÇŒ©‚Äã‚àëŒ≤‚Äã(œÉŒ±Œ≤‚ÄãœïiŒ±‚ÄãdnŒ≤‚Äã)

Topology optimization

simp(Solid Isotropic Material with Penalization)
oc(Optimility Criterion)
minimize deformation energy

The most common topology optimization problem is minimal compliance:
min‚Å°L(œÅ)=uTK(œÅ)us.t.K(œÅ)u=f‚àëeœÅe‚â§cVœÅe‚àà[œÅmin‚Å°,1]\begin{aligned} \min\quad L(\rho)&=u^TK(\rho)u\\ s.t. \quad K(\rho)u&=f\\ \sum_e \rho_e&\leq cV\\ \rho_e&\in [\rho_{\min},1]\\ \end{aligned}minL(œÅ)s.t.K(œÅ)ue‚àë‚ÄãœÅe‚ÄãœÅe‚Äã‚Äã=uTK(œÅ)u=f‚â§cV‚àà[œÅmin‚Äã,1]‚Äã

LLL: measure of deformation energy, or the loss function
ccc: volume fraction (c‚àà(0,1]c \in (0,1]c‚àà(0,1])
œÅe\rho_eœÅe‚Äã: material occupancy of cell eee (0=empty, 1=filled, œÅ\rhoœÅ is usually 10‚àí210^{-2}10‚àí2 or 10‚àí310^{-3}10‚àí3.)
VVV: total volume

Smoothed Particle Hydrodynamics (SPH)

For an overview of the concepts of SPH, refer to tutorial.

Navier-Stokes equations


Here mainly conservation of momentum is enforced.
Navier-Stokes equations express conservation of momentum (Newton‚Äôs second law),conservation of mass and conservation of energy and is used to describe viscous flow.
Density(œÅ\rhoœÅ), velocity(vvv), pressure(ppp), viscosity(Œº\muŒº) and temperature(TTT) are involved.
Refer to NS equations for details.

For low speed fluids incompressibility is assumed and the equations can be simplified while for high speed ones compressibility should be taken into consideration.

Courant-Friedrichs-Lewy(CFL) condition

Neighborhood search(NS)

Accelerating SPH:

For details of neighborhood list, refer to Neighbour lists in smoothed particle hydrodynamics.

SPH interpolation

In SPH, particles are used to interpolate a continuous function A(x)A(\mathbf{x})A(x) at a position x\mathbf{x}x.
For any continuous function AAA, the interpolation is given as
A(x)=‚àëjmjA(xj)œÅjW(x‚àíxj,h)A(\mathbf{x})=\sum_j m_j\frac{A(\mathbf{x}_j)}{\rho_j}W(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}_j,h)A(x)=j‚àë‚Äãmj‚ÄãœÅj‚ÄãA(xj‚Äã)‚ÄãW(x‚àíxj‚Äã,h)

Weakly compressible SPH (WCSPH)

This method allows for small, user-defined density fluctuations rather than strictly enforcing incompressibility to save time for solving Poisson equation. Actually a simplified pressure equation called Tait equation rather than pressure Poisson equation(PPE) is adopted.
Refer to WCSPH2007 for more details.

Kernel function

A commonly used kernel function in SPH is the cubic spline kernel Monaghan1992(actually there are many kinds of cubic spline kernelsüòÇ):
W(q)={œÉ3[1‚àí32q2+34q3],for‚ÄÖ‚Ää0‚â§q<1œÉ34(2‚àíq)3,for‚ÄÖ‚Ää1‚â§q<20,for‚ÄÖ‚Ääq‚â•2W(q)=\begin{cases} \sigma_3[1-\frac{3}{2}q^2+\frac{3}{4}q^3],\quad&\rm{for\; 0\leq q< 1}\\ \frac{\sigma_3}{4}(2-q)^3,&\rm{for\; 1\leq q< 2}\\ 0,&\rm{for\; q\ge 2}\\ \end{cases}W(q)=‚é©‚é™‚é™‚é®‚é™‚é™‚éß‚ÄãœÉ3‚Äã[1‚àí23‚Äãq2+43‚Äãq3],4œÉ3‚Äã‚Äã(2‚àíq)3,0,‚Äãfor0‚â§q<1for1‚â§q<2forq‚â•2‚Äã

where q=‚à•r‚à•hq=\frac{\|\mathbf{r}\|}{h}q=h‚à•r‚à•‚Äã and œÉ3\sigma_3œÉ3‚Äã is a dimensional normalizing factor given by:
œÉ3={23h,for‚ÄÖ‚Äädim=1107œÄh2,for‚ÄÖ‚Äädim=21œÄh3,for‚ÄÖ‚Äädim=2\sigma_3=\begin{cases} \frac{2}{3h},\quad&\rm{for\;dim=1}\\ \frac{10}{7\pi h^2},&\rm{for\;dim=2}\\ \frac{1}{\pi h^3},&\rm{for\;dim=2}\\ \end{cases}œÉ3‚Äã=‚é©‚é™‚é™‚é®‚é™‚é™‚éß‚Äã3h2‚Äã,7œÄh210‚Äã,œÄh31‚Äã,‚Äãfordim=1fordim=2fordim=2‚Äã

And the gradient of the kernel function ‚àáWij\nabla W_{ij}‚àáWij‚Äã which is commonly used in SPH is derived as
‚àáWij=dWijdq‚àór‚à•r‚à•=dWijdq‚àóxi‚àíxj‚à•xi‚àíxj‚à•\nabla W_{ij}=\frac{dW_{ij}}{dq}*\frac{\mathbf{r}}{\|\mathbf{r}\|}=\frac{dW_{ij}}{dq}*\frac{\mathbf{x}_i-\mathbf{x}_j}{\|\mathbf{x}_i-\mathbf{x}_j\|}‚àáWij‚Äã=dqdWij‚Äã‚Äã‚àó‚à•r‚à•r‚Äã=dqdWij‚Äã‚Äã‚àó‚à•xi‚Äã‚àíxj‚Äã‚à•xi‚Äã‚àíxj‚Äã‚Äã

Governing equations and their SPH formulation

Continuity equation

General form
dœÅdt=‚àíœÅ‚àá‚ãÖv\frac{d\rho}{dt}=-\rho\nabla\cdot\mathbf{v}dtdœÅ‚Äã=‚àíœÅ‚àá‚ãÖv

In SPH, the density is calculated as
œÅa=‚àëbmbWab\rho_a=\sum_bm_bW_{ab}œÅa‚Äã=b‚àë‚Äãmb‚ÄãWab‚Äã

where aaa is the current particle and bbb denotes its neighbors. Wab=W(xa‚àíxb)W_{ab}=W(\mathbf{x}_a-\mathbf{x}_b)Wab‚Äã=W(xa‚Äã‚àíxb‚Äã) is the kernel function value between aaa and bbb and ‚à•xa‚àíxb‚à•=r\|\mathbf{x}_a-\mathbf{x}_b\|=r‚à•xa‚Äã‚àíxb‚Äã‚à•=r in the kernel function.
And the derivative is
dœÅadt=‚àëbmbvab‚àáaWab\frac{d\rho_a}{dt}=\sum_bm_b\mathbf{v}_{ab}\nabla_aW_{ab}dtdœÅa‚Äã‚Äã=b‚àë‚Äãmb‚Äãvab‚Äã‚àáa‚ÄãWab‚Äã

where vab=va‚àívb\mathbf{v}_{ab}=\mathbf{v}_a-\mathbf{v}_bvab‚Äã=va‚Äã‚àívb‚Äã and ‚àáaWab=dWabdq‚àóxa‚àíxb‚à•xa‚àíxb‚à•\nabla_aW_{ab}=\frac{dW_{ab}}{dq}*\frac{\mathbf{x}_a-\mathbf{x}_b}{\|\mathbf{x}_a-\mathbf{x}_b\|}‚àáa‚ÄãWab‚Äã=dqdWab‚Äã‚Äã‚àó‚à•xa‚Äã‚àíxb‚Äã‚à•xa‚Äã‚àíxb‚Äã‚Äã are all vectors with q=‚à•xa‚àíxb‚à•hq=\frac{\|\mathbf{x}_a-\mathbf{x}_b\|}{h}q=h‚à•xa‚Äã‚àíxb‚Äã‚à•‚Äã.
For this method, density changes are only due to relative motion of particles.

Momentum equation

General form
dvdt=‚àí1œÅ‚àáp+g\frac{d\mathbf{v}}{dt}=-\frac{1}{\rho}\nabla p+\mathbf{g}dtdv‚Äã=‚àíœÅ1‚Äã‚àáp+g

SPH form (Pressure force + Body force)
dvadt=‚àí‚àëbmb(paœÅa2+pbœÅb2)‚àáaWab+g\frac{d\mathbf{v}_a}{dt}=-\sum_bm_b(\frac{p_a}{\rho_a^2}+\frac{p_b}{\rho_b^2})\nabla_aW_{ab}+\mathbf{g}dtdva‚Äã‚Äã=‚àíb‚àë‚Äãmb‚Äã(œÅa2‚Äãpa‚Äã‚Äã+œÅb2‚Äãpb‚Äã‚Äã)‚àáa‚ÄãWab‚Äã+g

Equation of state (EOS)

There are different form of EOS with different conditions. In WCSPH, low compressibily is adopted.

  • Incompressibility (Poisson equation)
    ‚àá2p=œÅ‚àá‚ãÖvŒît\nabla^2p=\rho\frac{\nabla\cdot\mathbf{v}}{\Delta t}‚àá2p=œÅŒît‚àá‚ãÖv‚Äã

    Solving this Poisson equation is time-consuming(PCG,MGPCG). Standard SPH and other methods like FVM directly solve this equation.

  • High compressibility (Ideal gas equation)
    p=kpœÅorp=kp(œÅ‚àíœÅ0)p=k_p\rho\quad {\rm or} \quad p=k_p(\rho-\rho_0)p=kp‚ÄãœÅorp=kp‚Äã(œÅ‚àíœÅ0‚Äã)

    This method requires a pressure constant kpk_pkp‚Äã and results in a high compressibility.

  • Low compressibility (Tait equation)
    p=B((œÅœÅ0)Œ≥‚àí1)B=Œ∫œÅ0Œ≥\begin{aligned} p&=B\left(\left(\frac{\rho}{\rho_0}\right)^\gamma-1\right)\\ B&=\frac{\kappa\rho_0}{\gamma} \end{aligned}pB‚Äã=B((œÅ0‚ÄãœÅ‚Äã)Œ≥‚àí1)=Œ≥Œ∫œÅ0‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã

    where œÅ0\rho_0œÅ0‚Äã is the initial particle density, Œ∫\kappaŒ∫ is a stiffness parameter and Œ≥\gammaŒ≥ is another parameter.
    Actually Œ∫\kappaŒ∫ should be determined based on the desired density variation through test and tuning. In WCSPH, Œ∫\kappaŒ∫ is assigned a large value Œ∫=cs2\kappa=c_s^2Œ∫=cs2‚Äã where csc_scs‚Äã denotes the speed of sound in the fluid and Œ≥=7\gamma=7Œ≥=7 is adopted.
    B=cs2œÅ0Œ≥B=\frac{c_s^2\rho_0}{\gamma}B=Œ≥cs2‚ÄãœÅ0‚Äã‚Äã

    This large stiffness parameter can help keep the density fluctuation small. The relative density fluctuation thus follows the following relation
    ‚à£ŒîœÅ‚à£œÅ0=‚à£œÅ‚àíœÅ0‚à£œÅ0‚àº‚à£vf‚à£2cs2\frac{|\Delta\rho|}{\rho_0}=\frac{|\rho-\rho_0|}{\rho_0} \sim \frac{|\mathbf{v}_f|^2}{c_s^2}œÅ0‚Äã‚à£ŒîœÅ‚à£‚Äã=œÅ0‚Äã‚à£œÅ‚àíœÅ0‚Äã‚à£‚Äã‚àºcs2‚Äã‚à£vf‚Äã‚à£2‚Äã

    where vf\mathbf{v}_fvf‚Äã denotes the speed of flow.
    If the sound speed is much larger than the flow speed (cs‚â´‚à£vf‚à£c_s\gg|\mathbf{v}_f|cs‚Äã‚â´‚à£vf‚Äã‚à£), the density variation can be controlled at a low level. Define Œ∑<‚à£vf‚à£2cs2\eta < \frac{|\mathbf{v}_f|^2}{c_s^2}Œ∑<cs2‚Äã‚à£vf‚Äã‚à£2‚Äã and Œ∑=0.01\eta=0.01Œ∑=0.01 is usually chosen to control the density variations of the order of 1%.
    However, large stiffness results in smaller time step and increases overall computation cost.

Viscosity

Artificial viscosity is employed to improve numerical stability and to allow for shock phenomena.
dvadt={‚àí‚àëbmbŒ†ab‚àáaWabvabTxab<00vabTxab‚â•0\frac{d\mathbf{v}_a}{dt}=\begin{cases} -\sum_b m_b\Pi_{ab}\nabla_aW_{ab} \qquad&\mathbf{v}_{ab}^T\mathbf{x}_{ab}<0\\ 0 &\mathbf{v}_{ab}^T\mathbf{x}_{ab}\ge0 \end{cases}dtdva‚Äã‚Äã={‚àí‚àëb‚Äãmb‚ÄãŒ†ab‚Äã‚àáa‚ÄãWab‚Äã0‚ÄãvabT‚Äãxab‚Äã<0vabT‚Äãxab‚Äã‚â•0‚Äã
Œ†ab\Pi_{ab}Œ†ab‚Äã is given as
Œ†ab=‚àíŒΩ(vabTxab‚à£xab‚à£2+Œµh2)\Pi_{ab}=-\nu\left(\frac{\mathbf{v}_{ab}^T\mathbf{x}_{ab}}{|\mathbf{x}_{ab}|^2+\varepsilon h^2}\right)Œ†ab‚Äã=‚àíŒΩ(‚à£xab‚Äã‚à£2+Œµh2vabT‚Äãxab‚Äã‚Äã)

with the viscous term ŒΩ=2Œ±hcsœÅa+œÅb\nu=\frac{2\alpha h c_s}{\rho_a+\rho_b}ŒΩ=œÅa‚Äã+œÅb‚Äã2Œ±hcs‚Äã‚Äã and the viscosity constant Œ±\alphaŒ± is usually in between 0.08 and 0.5. Œµh2\varepsilon h^2Œµh2 is introduced to avoid singularities for ‚à£xab‚à£=0|\mathbf{x}_{ab}|=0‚à£xab‚Äã‚à£=0 with Œµ=0.01\varepsilon=0.01Œµ=0.01.

Surface tension (Ë°®Èù¢Âº†Âäõ)

In WCSPH, a new surface tension model is adopted which relies on cohesion forces.
dvadt=‚àíŒ∫ma‚àëbmbWabxa‚àíxk‚à£xa‚àíxk‚à£\frac{d\mathbf{v}_a}{dt}=-\frac{\kappa}{m_a}\sum_bm_bW_{ab} \frac{\mathbf{x}_a-\mathbf{x}_k}{|\mathbf{x}_a-\mathbf{x}_k|}dtdva‚Äã‚Äã=‚àíma‚ÄãŒ∫‚Äãb‚àë‚Äãmb‚ÄãWab‚Äã‚à£xa‚Äã‚àíxk‚Äã‚à£xa‚Äã‚àíxk‚Äã‚Äã

The accuracy of the above equation is doubtful and a reasonable value of Œ∫\kappaŒ∫ is unknown yet. üò¢
Energy dissipation is a problem. Currently the particles in a rectangle will explode while forming a circle with only surface tension.



Boundary particles

fak\mathbf{f}_{ak}fak‚Äã is the force applied to a fluid particle aaa that collides with a boundary particle kkk.
fak=mkma+mkŒì(xa,xk)xa‚àíxk‚à£xa‚àíxk‚à£\mathbf{f}_{ak}=\frac{m_k}{m_a+m_k}\Gamma(\mathbf{x}_a,\mathbf{x}_k)\frac{\mathbf{x}_a-\mathbf{x}_k}{|\mathbf{x}_a-\mathbf{x}_k|}fak‚Äã=ma‚Äã+mk‚Äãmk‚Äã‚ÄãŒì(xa‚Äã,xk‚Äã)‚à£xa‚Äã‚àíxk‚Äã‚à£xa‚Äã‚àíxk‚Äã‚Äã
Œì\GammaŒì is defined as
Œì(xa,xk)=0.02cs2‚à£xa‚àíxk‚à£‚àó{230<q<23(2q‚àí32q2)23<q<112(2‚àíq)21<q<20otherwise\Gamma(\mathbf{x}_a,\mathbf{x}_k)=0.02\frac{c_s^2}{|\mathbf{x}_a-\mathbf{x}_k|}*\begin{cases} \frac{2}{3} & 0<q<\frac{2}{3}\\ (2q-\frac{3}{2}q^2)&\frac{2}{3}<q<1\\ \frac{1}{2}(2-q)^2&1<q<2\\ 0 & \rm{otherwise} \end{cases}Œì(xa‚Äã,xk‚Äã)=0.02‚à£xa‚Äã‚àíxk‚Äã‚à£cs2‚Äã‚Äã‚àó‚é©‚é™‚é™‚é™‚é™‚é®‚é™‚é™‚é™‚é™‚éß‚Äã32‚Äã(2q‚àí23‚Äãq2)21‚Äã(2‚àíq)20‚Äã0<q<32‚Äã32‚Äã<q<11<q<2otherwise‚Äã

with q=‚à£xa‚àíxk‚à£hq=\frac{|\mathbf{x}_a-\mathbf{x}_k|}{h}q=h‚à£xa‚Äã‚àíxk‚Äã‚à£‚Äã

And we have
dvadt=fakma\frac{d\mathbf{v}_a}{dt}=\frac{\mathbf{f}_{ak}}{m_a}dtdva‚Äã‚Äã=ma‚Äãfak‚Äã‚Äã

Time step

CFL condition is adopted.

Computation flow

  1. Initialization
    Initialize the position, density, velocity, pressure of each particle (fluid and boundary particles) as well as the background mesh grid (for neighborhood search).

  2. Neighborhood search
    For each particle, compute and store its neighboring particles (number and id).

  3. Compute Œî\DeltaŒî
    Compute dœÅdt\frac{d\rho}{dt}dtdœÅ‚Äã

    • Continuity equation
      dœÅadt=‚àëbmbvab‚àáaWab\frac{d\rho_a}{dt}=\sum_bm_b\mathbf{v}_{ab}\nabla_aW_{ab}dtdœÅa‚Äã‚Äã=b‚àë‚Äãmb‚Äãvab‚Äã‚àáa‚ÄãWab‚Äã

      where vab=va‚àívb\mathbf{v}_{ab}=\mathbf{v}_a-\mathbf{v}_bvab‚Äã=va‚Äã‚àívb‚Äã and ‚àáaWab=dWabdq‚àóxa‚àíxb‚à•xa‚àíxb‚à•\nabla_aW_{ab}=\frac{dW_{ab}}{dq}*\frac{\mathbf{x}_a-\mathbf{x}_b}{\|\mathbf{x}_a-\mathbf{x}_b\|}‚àáa‚ÄãWab‚Äã=dqdWab‚Äã‚Äã‚àó‚à•xa‚Äã‚àíxb‚Äã‚à•xa‚Äã‚àíxb‚Äã‚Äã are all vectors with q=‚à•xa‚àíxb‚à•hq=\frac{\|\mathbf{x}_a-\mathbf{x}_b\|}{h}q=h‚à•xa‚Äã‚àíxb‚Äã‚à•‚Äã.

    Compute dvdt\frac{d\mathbf{v}}{dt}dtdv‚Äã(Actually forces)

    • Viscosity(Viscosity force)
      dvadt={‚àí‚àëbmbŒ†ab‚àáaWabvabTxab<00vabTxab‚â•0\frac{d\mathbf{v}_a}{dt}=\begin{cases} -\sum_b m_b\Pi_{ab}\nabla_aW_{ab} \qquad&\mathbf{v}_{ab}^T\mathbf{x}_{ab}<0\\ 0 &\mathbf{v}_{ab}^T\mathbf{x}_{ab}\ge0 \end{cases}dtdva‚Äã‚Äã={‚àí‚àëb‚Äãmb‚ÄãŒ†ab‚Äã‚àáa‚ÄãWab‚Äã0‚ÄãvabT‚Äãxab‚Äã<0vabT‚Äãxab‚Äã‚â•0‚Äã

    • Momentum equation(Pressure force & Body force)
      dvadt=‚àí‚àëbmb(paœÅa2+pbœÅb2)‚àáaWab+g\frac{d\mathbf{v}_a}{dt}=-\sum_bm_b(\frac{p_a}{\rho_a^2}+\frac{p_b}{\rho_b^2})\nabla_aW_{ab}+\mathbf{g}dtdva‚Äã‚Äã=‚àíb‚àë‚Äãmb‚Äã(œÅa2‚Äãpa‚Äã‚Äã+œÅb2‚Äãpb‚Äã‚Äã)‚àáa‚ÄãWab‚Äã+g

    • Surface tension(Surface tension)
      dvadt=‚àíŒ∫ma‚àëbmbWabxa‚àíxk‚à£xa‚àíxk‚à£\frac{d\mathbf{v}_a}{dt}=-\frac{\kappa}{m_a}\sum_bm_bW_{ab} \frac{\mathbf{x}_a-\mathbf{x}_k}{|\mathbf{x}_a-\mathbf{x}_k|}dtdva‚Äã‚Äã=‚àíma‚ÄãŒ∫‚Äãb‚àë‚Äãmb‚ÄãWab‚Äã‚à£xa‚Äã‚àíxk‚Äã‚à£xa‚Äã‚àíxk‚Äã‚Äã

    Summarize these above terms together to get the final dvdt\frac{d\mathbf{v}}{dt}dtdv‚Äã. Surface tension is doubtful and is not suggested to use.üò¢

  4. Enforce boundary conditions
    Refer to boundary particles for details.

  5. Update variables
    Update position (fluid particle)
    xa+=va‚àóŒît\mathbf{x}_a+=\mathbf{v}_a*\Delta txa‚Äã+=va‚Äã‚àóŒît

    Update velocity (fluid particle)
    va+=dvdt‚àóŒît\mathbf{v}_a+=\frac{d\mathbf{v}}{dt}*\Delta tva‚Äã+=dtdv‚Äã‚àóŒît

    Update density
    œÅa+=dœÅdt‚àóŒît\rho_a+=\frac{d\rho}{dt}*\Delta tœÅa‚Äã+=dtdœÅ‚Äã‚àóŒît

    Update pressure
    p=B((œÅœÅ0)Œ≥‚àí1)\begin{aligned} p&=B\left(\left(\frac{\rho}{\rho_0}\right)^\gamma-1\right) \end{aligned}p‚Äã=B((œÅ0‚ÄãœÅ‚Äã)Œ≥‚àí1)‚Äã

    with B=œÅ0cs2Œ≥B=\frac{\rho_0 c_s^2}{\gamma}B=Œ≥œÅ0‚Äãcs2‚Äã‚Äã. Refer to Equation of state for details.

  6. Update time step Œît\Delta tŒît and return to step 2.
    Œît=Ccfl‚àómin‚Å°[dhvmax‚Å°,dhamax‚Å°,dhcs‚àó(œÅmax‚Å°œÅ0)Œ≥]\Delta t=C_{cfl}*\min\left[\frac{dh}{v_{\max}},\sqrt{\frac{dh}{a_{\max}}},\frac{dh}{c_s*\sqrt{(\frac{\rho_{\max}}{\rho_0})^\gamma}}\right]Œît=Ccfl‚Äã‚àómin‚é£‚é¢‚é°‚Äãvmax‚Äãdh‚Äã,amax‚Äãdh‚Äã‚Äã,cs‚Äã‚àó(œÅ0‚ÄãœÅmax‚Äã‚Äã)Œ≥‚Äãdh‚Äã‚é¶‚é•‚é§‚Äã

    CcflC_{cfl}Ccfl‚Äã is commonly set to 0.2.

Drawbacks

  • Stiffness value is difficult to determine before running the simulation. Thus parameter tuning is inevitable.
  • WCSPH imposes a severe time step restriction because of the large stiffness value. The larger the smaller time step it will be based on CFL condition.

Predictive-corrective incompressible SPH (PCISPH)

This method allows for small density fluctuations like WCSPH. A prediction-correction scheme is adopted to obtain a larger time step than WCSPH. Iteration is needed during the correction process until all particle density fluctuations are smaller than a given threshold.
Pressure is obtained by continuous correction rather than solving a PPE.

Density correction via pressure change

A density prediction-correction scheme is adopted to control the density variance. This involves direct prediction and following correction loop.
A scaling factor Œ¥\deltaŒ¥ is precomputed for a prototype particle with a filled neighborhood and is used for all particles including those without a filled neighborhood like the particles on the free surface.
Œ¥=‚àí1Œ≤(‚àí‚àëj‚àáWij‚ãÖ‚àëj‚àáWij‚àí‚àëj(‚àáWij‚ãÖ‚àáWij))\delta=\frac{-1}{\beta(-\sum_j\nabla W_{ij}\cdot\sum_j\nabla W_{ij}-\sum_j(\nabla W_{ij}\cdot\nabla W_{ij}))}Œ¥=Œ≤(‚àí‚àëj‚Äã‚àáWij‚Äã‚ãÖ‚àëj‚Äã‚àáWij‚Äã‚àí‚àëj‚Äã(‚àáWij‚Äã‚ãÖ‚àáWij‚Äã))‚àí1‚Äã

where Œ≤=Œît2m22œÅ02\beta=\Delta t^2 m^2 \frac{2}{\rho_0^2}Œ≤=Œît2m2œÅ02‚Äã2‚Äã and ‚àáWij=dWijdq‚àóxi‚àíxj‚à•xi‚àíxj‚à•\nabla W_{ij}=\frac{dW_{ij}}{dq}*\frac{\mathbf{x}_i-\mathbf{x}_j}{\|\mathbf{x}_i-\mathbf{x}_j\|}‚àáWij‚Äã=dqdWij‚Äã‚Äã‚àó‚à•xi‚Äã‚àíxj‚Äã‚à•xi‚Äã‚àíxj‚Äã‚Äã with q=‚à•xi‚àíxj‚à•hq=\frac{\|\mathbf{x}_i-\mathbf{x}_j\|}{h}q=h‚à•xi‚Äã‚àíxj‚Äã‚à•‚Äã.
And the corrective pressure p~i\tilde p_ip~‚Äãi‚Äã which aims to correct the density variation is given as
p~i=Œ¥œÅerri‚àó\tilde p_i=\delta\rho^*_{err_i}p~‚Äãi‚Äã=Œ¥œÅerri‚Äã‚àó‚Äã

where œÅerri‚àó=œÅi‚àó‚àíœÅ0\rho^*_{err_i}=\rho^*_i-\rho_0œÅerri‚Äã‚àó‚Äã=œÅi‚àó‚Äã‚àíœÅ0‚Äã is the predicted density error of a particle.
And the corrected pressure is updated
pi+=p~ip_i+=\tilde p_ipi‚Äã+=p~‚Äãi‚Äã

This prediction-correction process will repeat until the density variance of each particle reaches the desired threshold.

Computation flow

  1. Initialization

Iteration 1 While t<tmax‚Å°t<t_{\max}t<tmax‚Äã:

  1. Neighborhood search

  2. Compute dvdt\frac{d\mathbf{v}}{dt}dtdv‚Äã(Actually forces)

    • Viscosity(Viscosity force)
      dvadt={‚àí‚àëbmbŒ†ab‚àáaWabvabTxab<00vabTxab‚â•0\frac{d\mathbf{v}_a}{dt}=\begin{cases} -\sum_b m_b\Pi_{ab}\nabla_aW_{ab} \qquad&\mathbf{v}_{ab}^T\mathbf{x}_{ab}<0\\ 0 &\mathbf{v}_{ab}^T\mathbf{x}_{ab}\ge0 \end{cases}dtdva‚Äã‚Äã={‚àí‚àëb‚Äãmb‚ÄãŒ†ab‚Äã‚àáa‚ÄãWab‚Äã0‚ÄãvabT‚Äãxab‚Äã<0vabT‚Äãxab‚Äã‚â•0‚Äã

    • Body force
      dvadt=g\frac{d\mathbf{v}_a}{dt}=\mathbf{g}dtdva‚Äã‚Äã=g

    Summarize these together dvidt=Viscosity+Body\frac{d\mathbf{v}_i}{dt}={\rm Viscosity+Body}dtdvi‚Äã‚Äã=Viscosity+Body to get the final acceleration of each particle without the contribution of pressure.(Pressure force changes during the iteration thus not precomputed here.)

  3. Initialize pressure
    pi=0anddvipdt=0p_i=0\quad{\rm and}\quad\frac{d\mathbf{v}_{ip}}{dt}=0pi‚Äã=0anddtdvip‚Äã‚Äã=0

    where pip_ipi‚Äã denotes the pressure of each particle and dvipdt\frac{d\mathbf{v}_{ip}}{dt}dtdvip‚Äã‚Äã denotes the acceleration of each particle caused by pressure force which changes during iteration.

  4. Compute scaling factor
    Œ¥=‚àí1Œ≤(‚àí‚àëj‚àáWij‚ãÖ‚àëj‚àáWij‚àí‚àëj(‚àáWij‚ãÖ‚àáWij))\delta=\frac{-1}{\beta(-\sum_j\nabla W_{ij}\cdot\sum_j\nabla W_{ij}-\sum_j(\nabla W_{ij}\cdot\nabla W_{ij}))}Œ¥=Œ≤(‚àí‚àëj‚Äã‚àáWij‚Äã‚ãÖ‚àëj‚Äã‚àáWij‚Äã‚àí‚àëj‚Äã(‚àáWij‚Äã‚ãÖ‚àáWij‚Äã))‚àí1‚Äã

    This is computed for a prototype particle with a filled neighborhood and is used for all particles. It is still unclear what the prototype particle looks like.üò¢

Iteration 2 While œÅerrmax‚Å°‚àó>threshold\rho^*_{err\max} > {\rm threshold}œÅerrmax‚àó‚Äã>threshold:

  1. Compute predicted variables

    • Compute predicted velocity
      vi‚àó=vi+Œît(dvidt+dvipdt)\mathbf{v}^*_i=\mathbf{v}_i+\Delta t (\frac{d\mathbf{v}_i}{dt}+\frac{d\mathbf{v}_{ip}}{dt})vi‚àó‚Äã=vi‚Äã+Œît(dtdvi‚Äã‚Äã+dtdvip‚Äã‚Äã)

      where ‚àó*‚àó denotes predicted value, iii denotes each particle and dvipdt\frac{d\mathbf{v}_{ip}}{dt}dtdvip‚Äã‚Äã denotes acceleration resulting from pressure force.

    • Compute predicted position
      xi‚àó=xi+Œîtvi‚àó\mathbf{x}_i^*=\mathbf{x}_i+\Delta t\mathbf{v}_i^*xi‚àó‚Äã=xi‚Äã+Œîtvi‚àó‚Äã

    Note: vi\mathbf{v}_ivi‚Äã, xi\mathbf{x}_ixi‚Äã and the following œÅi\rho_iœÅi‚Äã keep unchanged during iteration 2.

  2. Compute corrected pressure

    • Compute dœÅdt\frac{d\rho}{dt}dtdœÅ‚Äã
      Continuity equation
      dœÅidt=‚àëjmjvij‚àáWij\frac{d\rho_i}{dt}=\sum_jm_j\mathbf{v}_{ij}\nabla W_{ij}dtdœÅi‚Äã‚Äã=j‚àë‚Äãmj‚Äãvij‚Äã‚àáWij‚Äã

    In the given code, mjm_jmj‚Äã is not considered in the equation. Still unclear the reason behind that.üò¢

    • Compute predicted density
      œÅi‚àó=œÅi+ŒîtdœÅdt\rho^*_i=\rho_i+\Delta t\frac{d\rho}{dt}œÅi‚àó‚Äã=œÅi‚Äã+ŒîtdtdœÅ‚Äã
    • Compute density error
      œÅerri‚àó=œÅi‚àó‚àíœÅ0i\rho^*_{erri}=\rho^*_i-\rho_{0i}œÅerri‚àó‚Äã=œÅi‚àó‚Äã‚àíœÅ0i‚Äã
    • Update predicted pressure
      pi+=Œ¥œÅerri‚àóp_i+=\delta\rho^*_{erri}pi‚Äã+=Œ¥œÅerri‚àó‚Äã

    dvipdt=‚àí‚àëjmj(piœÅi2+pjœÅj2)‚àáWij\frac{d\mathbf{v}_{ip}}{dt}=-\sum_jm_j(\frac{p_i}{\rho_i^2}+\frac{p_j}{\rho_j^2})\nabla W_{ij}dtdvip‚Äã‚Äã=‚àíj‚àë‚Äãmj‚Äã(œÅi2‚Äãpi‚Äã‚Äã+œÅj2‚Äãpj‚Äã‚Äã)‚àáWij‚Äã

End Iteration 2

  1. Update variables
    vi+=Œît(dvidt+dvipdt)xi+=xi+ŒîtviœÅi+=ŒîtdœÅidt\begin{aligned} \mathbf{v}_i&+=\Delta t (\frac{d\mathbf{v}_i}{dt}+\frac{d\mathbf{v}_{ip}}{dt})\\ \mathbf{x}_i&+=\mathbf{x}_i+\Delta t \mathbf{v}_i\\ \rho_i&+=\Delta t \frac{d\rho_i}{dt}\\ \end{aligned}vi‚Äãxi‚ÄãœÅi‚Äã‚Äã+=Œît(dtdvi‚Äã‚Äã+dtdvip‚Äã‚Äã)+=xi‚Äã+Œîtvi‚Äã+=ŒîtdtdœÅi‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã

  2. Enforce boundary particles (Same as WCSPH)

  3. Adapt time step Œît\Delta tŒît
    Œît=min‚Å°[CCFLvdhvmax‚Å°,CCFLadhamax‚Å°]\Delta t=\min\left[C_{CFLv}\frac{dh}{v_{\max}},C_{CFLa}\sqrt{\frac{dh}{a_{\max}}}\right]Œît=min[CCFLv‚Äãvmax‚Äãdh‚Äã,CCFLa‚Äãamax‚Äãdh‚Äã‚Äã]

    Usually CCFLv=0.25C_{CFLv}=0.25CCFLv‚Äã=0.25 and CCFLa=0.05C_{CFLa}=0.05CCFLa‚Äã=0.05.

End Iteration 1

Note üê∂ about implementation

  • The neighborhood search is only executed once for each time step and the neighbor information is reused in the prediction process.
  • A minimum number of iteration is used in the prediction correction loop to limit temporal fluctuations in the pressure field. 3 is chosen as the minimum number.

The comparison of algorithms used in WCSPH and PCISPH is summarized below.

Implicit incompressible SPH (IISPH)

IISPH adopts a semi-implicit scheme. The semi-implicit scheme is achieved by separating non-pressure forces and pressure forces apart with an intermediate state. For non-pressure forces, the intermediate state is explicitly achieved. For pressure forces, a linear system of equations should be implicitly resolved.
This system of linear equations is solved for pressure using relaxed Jacobi iteration method while enforcing the constant density condition.

Continuity equation in IISPH

For continuity equation
DœÅDt=‚àíœÅ‚àá‚ãÖv\frac{D\rho}{Dt}=-\rho\nabla\cdot\mathbf{v}DtDœÅ‚Äã=‚àíœÅ‚àá‚ãÖv

The terms of it can be expressed as
DœÅiDt=œÅi(t+Œît)‚àíœÅi(t)Œît‚àá‚ãÖvi=‚àí1œÅi‚àëjmjvij‚àáWij\begin{aligned} \frac{D\rho_i}{Dt}&=\frac{\rho_i(t+\Delta t)-\rho_i(t)}{\Delta t}\\ \nabla\cdot\mathbf{v}_i&=-\frac{1}{\rho_i}\sum_jm_j\mathbf{v}_{ij}\nabla W_{ij}\\ \end{aligned}DtDœÅi‚Äã‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖvi‚Äã‚Äã=ŒîtœÅi‚Äã(t+Œît)‚àíœÅi‚Äã(t)‚Äã=‚àíœÅi‚Äã1‚Äãj‚àë‚Äãmj‚Äãvij‚Äã‚àáWij‚Äã‚Äã

Thus the continuity equation can be rewritten in IISPH as
œÅi(t+Œît)‚àíœÅi(t)Œît=‚àëjmjvij(t+Œît)‚àáWij\frac{\rho_i(t+\Delta t)-\rho_i(t)}{\Delta t}=\sum_jm_j\mathbf{v}_{ij}(t+\Delta t)\nabla W_{ij}ŒîtœÅi‚Äã(t+Œît)‚àíœÅi‚Äã(t)‚Äã=j‚àë‚Äãmj‚Äãvij‚Äã(t+Œît)‚àáWij‚Äã

where vij(t+Œît)=vi(t+Œît)‚àívj(t+Œît)\mathbf{v}_{ij}(t+\Delta t)=\mathbf{v}_i(t+\Delta t)-\mathbf{v}_j(t+\Delta t)vij‚Äã(t+Œît)=vi‚Äã(t+Œît)‚àívj‚Äã(t+Œît).

Pressure and non-pressure force

For the continuity equation in IISPH
vi(t+Œît)=vi(t)+ŒîtFiadv(t)+Fip(t)mi\mathbf{v}_i(t+\Delta t)=\mathbf{v}_i(t)+\Delta t\frac{\mathbf{F}_i^{adv}(t)+\mathbf{F}_i^p(t)}{m_i}vi‚Äã(t+Œît)=vi‚Äã(t)+Œîtmi‚ÄãFiadv‚Äã(t)+Fip‚Äã(t)‚Äã

where Fip(t)\mathbf{F}_i^{p}(t)Fip‚Äã(t) is the pressure force and Fiadv(t)\mathbf{F}_i^{adv}(t)Fiadv‚Äã(t) is the non-pressure force including viscosity, body force(ggg) and surface tension.
Non-pressure force is known and can be obtained by
Fiadv(t)=Fiviscosity(t)+mig+Fisurfacetension(t)\mathbf{F}_i^{adv}(t)=\mathbf{F}^{viscosity}_i(t)+m_ig+\mathbf{F}^{surface tension}_i(t)Fiadv‚Äã(t)=Fiviscosity‚Äã(t)+mi‚Äãg+Fisurfacetension‚Äã(t)

Pressure force is unknown and can be expressed (similar to momentum equation) as
Fip(t)=‚àími‚àëjmj(pi(t)œÅi2(t)+pj(t)œÅj2(t))‚àáWij(t)\mathbf{F}_i^{p}(t)=-m_i\sum_jm_j\left(\frac{p_i(t)}{\rho_i^2(t)}+\frac{p_j(t)}{\rho_j^2(t)}\right)\nabla W_{ij}(t)Fip‚Äã(t)=‚àími‚Äãj‚àë‚Äãmj‚Äã(œÅi2‚Äã(t)pi‚Äã(t)‚Äã+œÅj2‚Äã(t)pj‚Äã(t)‚Äã)‚àáWij‚Äã(t)

where pressure p(t)p(t)p(t) is unknown.

For each particle in SPH, m,œÅ,v,x,pm,\rho,\mathbf{v},\mathbf{x},pm,œÅ,v,x,p are the 5 key particle features. In IISPH, m,œÅm,\rhom,œÅ assume unchanged during the process and the key point is to solve for pressure.

Semi-implicit scheme

Based on the above equations, a semi-implicit scheme can be derived.
Explicit part
An intermediate state is introduced where the known non-pressure force is firstly used to get the intermediate velocity viadv\mathbf{v}_i^{adv}viadv‚Äã and density œÅiadv\rho_i^{adv}œÅiadv‚Äã.
viadv=vi(t)+ŒîtFiadv(t)miœÅiadv‚àíœÅi(t)Œît=‚àëjmjvijadv‚àáWij(t)‚áíœÅiadv=œÅi(t)+Œît‚àëjmjvijadv‚àáWij(t)\begin{aligned} \mathbf{v}_i^{adv}&=\mathbf{v}_i(t)+\Delta t\frac{\mathbf{F}_i^{adv}(t)}{m_i}\\ \frac{\rho_i^{adv}-\rho_i(t)}{\Delta t}=\sum_jm_j\mathbf{v}^{adv}_{ij}\nabla W_{ij}(t) \Rightarrow \rho_i^{adv}&=\rho_i(t)+\Delta t\sum_jm_j\mathbf{v}^{adv}_{ij}\nabla W_{ij}(t) \end{aligned}viadv‚ÄãŒîtœÅiadv‚Äã‚àíœÅi‚Äã(t)‚Äã=j‚àë‚Äãmj‚Äãvijadv‚Äã‚àáWij‚Äã(t)‚áíœÅiadv‚Äã‚Äã=vi‚Äã(t)+Œîtmi‚ÄãFiadv‚Äã(t)‚Äã=œÅi‚Äã(t)+Œîtj‚àë‚Äãmj‚Äãvijadv‚Äã‚àáWij‚Äã(t)‚Äã

where vijadv=viadv‚àívjadv\mathbf{v}^{adv}_{ij}=\mathbf{v}^{adv}_{i}-\mathbf{v}^{adv}_{j}vijadv‚Äã=viadv‚Äã‚àívjadv‚Äã.
Implicit part
Based on the intermediate state, pressure force is involved in the implicit part to solve for unknown pressure.
Œît2‚àëjmj(Fip(t)mi‚àíFjp(t)mj)‚àáWij(t)=œÅ0‚àíœÅiadv\Delta t^2\sum_jm_j\left(\frac{\mathbf{F}_i^p(t)}{m_i}-\frac{\mathbf{F}_j^p(t)}{m_j}\right)\nabla W_{ij}(t)=\rho_0-\rho_i^{adv}Œît2j‚àë‚Äãmj‚Äã(mi‚ÄãFip‚Äã(t)‚Äã‚àímj‚ÄãFjp‚Äã(t)‚Äã)‚àáWij‚Äã(t)=œÅ0‚Äã‚àíœÅiadv‚Äã

The derivation of the above equation is based on the continuity equation and the assumption that œÅi(t+Œît)=œÅ0\rho_i(t+\Delta t)=\rho_0œÅi‚Äã(t+Œît)=œÅ0‚Äã.
œÅi(t+Œît)‚àíœÅi(t)Œît=‚àëjmjvij(t+Œît)‚àáWijœÅ0‚àíœÅi(t)Œît=‚àëjmjvij(t+Œît)‚àáWijœÅ0‚àíœÅi(t)Œît=‚àëjmj(vi(t+Œît)‚àívj(t+Œît))‚àáWijœÅ0‚àíœÅi(t)Œît=‚àëjmj[(vi(t)+ŒîtFiadv(t)mi+ŒîtFip(t)mi)‚àí(vi(t)+ŒîtFjadv(t)mj+ŒîtFjp(t)mj)]‚àáWijœÅ0‚àíœÅi(t)Œît=‚àëjmj[(vi(t)+ŒîtFiadv(t)mi)‚àí(vi(t)+ŒîtFjadv(t)mj)]‚àáWij+‚àëjmj(ŒîtFip(t)mi‚àíŒîtFjp(t)mj)‚àáWijœÅ0‚àíœÅi(t)Œît=‚àëjmj(viadv‚àívjadv)‚àáWij+Œît‚àëjmj(Fip(t)mi‚àíFjp(t)mj)‚àáWijœÅ0‚àíœÅi(t)Œît=œÅiadv‚àíœÅi(t)Œît+Œît‚àëjmj(Fip(t)mi‚àíFjp(t)mj)‚àáWijœÅ0‚àíœÅiadvŒît=Œît‚àëjmj(Fip(t)mi‚àíFjp(t)mj)‚àáWijœÅ0‚àíœÅiadv=Œît2‚àëjmj(Fip(t)mi‚àíFjp(t)mj)‚àáWij\begin{aligned} \frac{\rho_i(t+\Delta t)-\rho_i(t)}{\Delta t}&=\sum_jm_j\mathbf{v}_{ij}(t+\Delta t)\nabla W_{ij}\\ \frac{\rho_0-\rho_i(t)}{\Delta t}&=\sum_jm_j\mathbf{v}_{ij}(t+\Delta t)\nabla W_{ij}\\ \frac{\rho_0-\rho_i(t)}{\Delta t}&=\sum_jm_j(\mathbf{v}_{i}(t+\Delta t)-\mathbf{v}_{j}(t+\Delta t))\nabla W_{ij}\\ \frac{\rho_0-\rho_i(t)}{\Delta t}&=\sum_jm_j\left[\left(\mathbf{v}_i(t)+\Delta t\frac{\mathbf{F}_i^{adv}(t)}{m_i}+\Delta t\frac{\mathbf{F}_i^p(t)}{m_i}\right)-\left(\mathbf{v}_i(t)+\Delta t\frac{\mathbf{F}_j^{adv}(t)}{m_j}+\Delta t\frac{\mathbf{F}_j^p(t)}{m_j}\right)\right]\nabla W_{ij}\\ \frac{\rho_0-\rho_i(t)}{\Delta t}&=\sum_jm_j\left[\left(\mathbf{v}_i(t)+\Delta t\frac{\mathbf{F}_i^{adv}(t)}{m_i}\right)-\left(\mathbf{v}_i(t)+\Delta t\frac{\mathbf{F}_j^{adv}(t)}{m_j}\right)\right]\nabla W_{ij}+\sum_jm_j\left(\Delta t\frac{\mathbf{F}_i^p(t)}{m_i}-\Delta t\frac{\mathbf{F}_j^p(t)}{m_j}\right)\nabla W_{ij}\\ \frac{\rho_0-\rho_i(t)}{\Delta t}&=\sum_jm_j(\mathbf{v}_i^{adv}-\mathbf{v}_j^{adv})\nabla W_{ij}+\Delta t\sum_jm_j\left(\frac{\mathbf{F}_i^p(t)}{m_i}-\frac{\mathbf{F}_j^p(t)}{m_j}\right)\nabla W_{ij}\\ \frac{\rho_0-\rho_i(t)}{\Delta t}&=\frac{\rho_i^{adv}-\rho_i(t)}{\Delta t}+\Delta t\sum_jm_j\left(\frac{\mathbf{F}_i^p(t)}{m_i}-\frac{\mathbf{F}_j^p(t)}{m_j}\right)\nabla W_{ij}\\ \frac{\rho_0-\rho_i^{adv}}{\Delta t}&=\Delta t\sum_jm_j\left(\frac{\mathbf{F}_i^p(t)}{m_i}-\frac{\mathbf{F}_j^p(t)}{m_j}\right)\nabla W_{ij}\\ \rho_0-\rho_i^{adv}&=\Delta t^2\sum_jm_j\left(\frac{\mathbf{F}_i^p(t)}{m_i}-\frac{\mathbf{F}_j^p(t)}{m_j}\right)\nabla W_{ij}\\ \end{aligned}ŒîtœÅi‚Äã(t+Œît)‚àíœÅi‚Äã(t)‚ÄãŒîtœÅ0‚Äã‚àíœÅi‚Äã(t)‚ÄãŒîtœÅ0‚Äã‚àíœÅi‚Äã(t)‚ÄãŒîtœÅ0‚Äã‚àíœÅi‚Äã(t)‚ÄãŒîtœÅ0‚Äã‚àíœÅi‚Äã(t)‚ÄãŒîtœÅ0‚Äã‚àíœÅi‚Äã(t)‚ÄãŒîtœÅ0‚Äã‚àíœÅi‚Äã(t)‚ÄãŒîtœÅ0‚Äã‚àíœÅiadv‚Äã‚ÄãœÅ0‚Äã‚àíœÅiadv‚Äã‚Äã=j‚àë‚Äãmj‚Äãvij‚Äã(t+Œît)‚àáWij‚Äã=j‚àë‚Äãmj‚Äãvij‚Äã(t+Œît)‚àáWij‚Äã=j‚àë‚Äãmj‚Äã(vi‚Äã(t+Œît)‚àívj‚Äã(t+Œît))‚àáWij‚Äã=j‚àë‚Äãmj‚Äã[(vi‚Äã(t)+Œîtmi‚ÄãFiadv‚Äã(t)‚Äã+Œîtmi‚ÄãFip‚Äã(t)‚Äã)‚àí(vi‚Äã(t)+Œîtmj‚ÄãFjadv‚Äã(t)‚Äã+Œîtmj‚ÄãFjp‚Äã(t)‚Äã)]‚àáWij‚Äã=j‚àë‚Äãmj‚Äã[(vi‚Äã(t)+Œîtmi‚ÄãFiadv‚Äã(t)‚Äã)‚àí(vi‚Äã(t)+Œîtmj‚ÄãFjadv‚Äã(t)‚Äã)]‚àáWij‚Äã+j‚àë‚Äãmj‚Äã(Œîtmi‚ÄãFip‚Äã(t)‚Äã‚àíŒîtmj‚ÄãFjp‚Äã(t)‚Äã)‚àáWij‚Äã=j‚àë‚Äãmj‚Äã(viadv‚Äã‚àívjadv‚Äã)‚àáWij‚Äã+Œîtj‚àë‚Äãmj‚Äã(mi‚ÄãFip‚Äã(t)‚Äã‚àímj‚ÄãFjp‚Äã(t)‚Äã)‚àáWij‚Äã=ŒîtœÅiadv‚Äã‚àíœÅi‚Äã(t)‚Äã+Œîtj‚àë‚Äãmj‚Äã(mi‚ÄãFip‚Äã(t)‚Äã‚àímj‚ÄãFjp‚Äã(t)‚Äã)‚àáWij‚Äã=Œîtj‚àë‚Äãmj‚Äã(mi‚ÄãFip‚Äã(t)‚Äã‚àímj‚ÄãFjp‚Äã(t)‚Äã)‚àáWij‚Äã=Œît2j‚àë‚Äãmj‚Äã(mi‚ÄãFip‚Äã(t)‚Äã‚àímj‚ÄãFjp‚Äã(t)‚Äã)‚àáWij‚Äã‚Äã

Substitute the pressure force in the above equation, we have
œÅ0‚àíœÅiadv=Œît2‚àëjmj((‚àí‚àëjmj(pi(t)œÅi2(t)+pj(t)œÅj2(t))‚àáWij)‚àí(‚àí‚àëkmk(pj(t)œÅj2(t)+pk(t)œÅk2(t))‚àáWjk))‚àáWij=‚àëjmj((‚àíŒît2‚àëjmjœÅi2‚àáWij)pi+‚àëj(‚àíŒît2mjœÅj2‚àáWijpj)‚àí(‚àíŒît2‚àëkmkœÅj2‚àáWjk)pj‚àí‚àëk(‚àíŒît2mkœÅk2‚àáWjkpk))‚àáWij=‚àëjmj(diipi+‚àëjdijpj‚àídjjpj‚àí‚àëkdjkpk)‚àáWij\begin{aligned} \rho_0-\rho_i^{adv}&=\Delta t^2\sum_jm_j((-\sum_jm_j\left(\frac{p_i(t)}{\rho_i^2(t)}+\frac{p_j(t)}{\rho_j^2(t)}\right)\nabla W_{ij})-(-\sum_km_k\left(\frac{p_j(t)}{\rho_j^2(t)}+\frac{p_k(t)}{\rho_k^2(t)}\right)\nabla W_{jk}))\nabla W_{ij}\\ &=\sum_jm_j\left((-\Delta t^2\sum_j\frac{m_j}{\rho_i^2}\nabla W_{ij})p_i+\sum_j(-\Delta t^2\frac{m_j}{\rho_j^2}\nabla W_{ij}p_j)-(-\Delta t^2\sum_k\frac{m_k}{\rho_j^2}\nabla W_{jk})p_j-\sum_k(-\Delta t^2\frac{m_k}{\rho_k^2}\nabla W_{jk}p_k)\right)\nabla W_{ij}\\ &=\sum_jm_j(\mathbf{d}_{ii}p_i+\sum_j\mathbf{d}_{ij}p_j-\mathbf{d}_{jj}p_j-\sum_k\mathbf{d}_{jk}p_k)\nabla W_{ij} \end{aligned}œÅ0‚Äã‚àíœÅiadv‚Äã‚Äã=Œît2j‚àë‚Äãmj‚Äã((‚àíj‚àë‚Äãmj‚Äã(œÅi2‚Äã(t)pi‚Äã(t)‚Äã+œÅj2‚Äã(t)pj‚Äã(t)‚Äã)‚àáWij‚Äã)‚àí(‚àík‚àë‚Äãmk‚Äã(œÅj2‚Äã(t)pj‚Äã(t)‚Äã+œÅk2‚Äã(t)pk‚Äã(t)‚Äã)‚àáWjk‚Äã))‚àáWij‚Äã=j‚àë‚Äãmj‚Äã((‚àíŒît2j‚àë‚ÄãœÅi2‚Äãmj‚Äã‚Äã‚àáWij‚Äã)pi‚Äã+j‚àë‚Äã(‚àíŒît2œÅj2‚Äãmj‚Äã‚Äã‚àáWij‚Äãpj‚Äã)‚àí(‚àíŒît2k‚àë‚ÄãœÅj2‚Äãmk‚Äã‚Äã‚àáWjk‚Äã)pj‚Äã‚àík‚àë‚Äã(‚àíŒît2œÅk2‚Äãmk‚Äã‚Äã‚àáWjk‚Äãpk‚Äã))‚àáWij‚Äã=j‚àë‚Äãmj‚Äã(dii‚Äãpi‚Äã+j‚àë‚Äãdij‚Äãpj‚Äã‚àídjj‚Äãpj‚Äã‚àík‚àë‚Äãdjk‚Äãpk‚Äã)‚àáWij‚Äã‚Äã

with
dii=‚àíŒît2‚àëjmjœÅi2‚àáWijdij=‚àíŒît2mjœÅj2‚àáWij\begin{aligned} \mathbf{d}_{ii}&=-\Delta t^2\sum_j\frac{m_j}{\rho_i^2}\nabla W_{ij}\\ \mathbf{d}_{ij}&=-\Delta t^2\frac{m_j}{\rho_j^2}\nabla W_{ij}\\ \end{aligned}dii‚Äãdij‚Äã‚Äã=‚àíŒît2j‚àë‚ÄãœÅi2‚Äãmj‚Äã‚Äã‚àáWij‚Äã=‚àíŒît2œÅj2‚Äãmj‚Äã‚Äã‚àáWij‚Äã‚Äã

The above equation can be further written as the following form by extracting unknown pressure. [KEY EQUATION]
œÅ0‚àíœÅiadv=‚àëjmj(diipi+‚àëjdijpj‚àídjjpj‚àí‚àëkdjkpk)‚àáWij=pi‚àëjmj(dii‚àídji)‚àáWij+‚àëjmj(‚àëjdijpj‚àídjjpj‚àí‚àëk‚â†idjkpk)‚àáWij\begin{aligned} \rho_0-\rho_i^{adv}&=\sum_jm_j(\mathbf{d}_{ii}p_i+\sum_j\mathbf{d}_{ij}p_j-\mathbf{d}_{jj}p_j-\sum_k\mathbf{d}_{jk}p_k)\nabla W_{ij}\\ &=p_i\sum_jm_j(\mathbf{d}_{ii}-\mathbf{d}_{ji})\nabla W_{ij}+\sum_jm_j(\sum_j\mathbf{d}_{ij}p_j-\mathbf{d}_{jj}p_j-\sum_{k\neq i}\mathbf{d}_{jk}p_k)\nabla W_{ij} \end{aligned}œÅ0‚Äã‚àíœÅiadv‚Äã‚Äã=j‚àë‚Äãmj‚Äã(dii‚Äãpi‚Äã+j‚àë‚Äãdij‚Äãpj‚Äã‚àídjj‚Äãpj‚Äã‚àík‚àë‚Äãdjk‚Äãpk‚Äã)‚àáWij‚Äã=pi‚Äãj‚àë‚Äãmj‚Äã(dii‚Äã‚àídji‚Äã)‚àáWij‚Äã+j‚àë‚Äãmj‚Äã(j‚àë‚Äãdij‚Äãpj‚Äã‚àídjj‚Äãpj‚Äã‚àíkÓÄ†‚Äã=i‚àë‚Äãdjk‚Äãpk‚Äã)‚àáWij‚Äã‚Äã

Thus this can be written in matrix form
A(t)p(t)=b(t)\mathbf{A}(t)\mathbf{p}(t)=\mathbf{b}(t)A(t)p(t)=b(t)

where b(t)=[œÅ0‚àíœÅ1adv,œÅ0‚àíœÅ2adv,‚Ä¶‚Äâ]T\mathbf{b}(t)=[\rho_0-\rho_1^{adv},\rho_0-\rho_2^{adv},\dots]^Tb(t)=[œÅ0‚Äã‚àíœÅ1adv‚Äã,œÅ0‚Äã‚àíœÅ2adv‚Äã,‚Ä¶]T and p(t)=[p1,p2,‚Ä¶‚Äâ]T\mathbf{p}(t)=[p_1,p_2,\dots]^Tp(t)=[p1‚Äã,p2‚Äã,‚Ä¶]T are the unknowns.
For this system of linear equations, relaxed Jacobi method is adopted.
The coefficient matrix is divided into diagonal and non-diagonal matrices with nnn denoting the total number of particles.
A(t)=D+R\mathbf{A}(t)=\mathbf{D}+\mathbf{R}A(t)=D+R

where
D=[a110‚ãØ00a22‚ãØ0‚ãÆ‚ãÆ‚ã±‚ãÆ00‚ãØann]\mathbf{D}=\begin{bmatrix} a_{11} & 0 & \cdots & 0\\ 0 & a_{22} & \cdots & 0\\ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots\\ 0 & 0 & \cdots & a_{nn}\\ \end{bmatrix}D=‚é£‚é¢‚é¢‚é¢‚é¢‚é°‚Äãa11‚Äã0‚ãÆ0‚Äã0a22‚Äã‚ãÆ0‚Äã‚ãØ‚ãØ‚ã±‚ãØ‚Äã00‚ãÆann‚Äã‚Äã‚é¶‚é•‚é•‚é•‚é•‚é§‚Äã

R=[0a12‚ãØa1na210‚ãØa2n‚ãÆ‚ãÆ‚ã±‚ãÆan1an2‚ãØ0]\mathbf{R}=\begin{bmatrix} 0 & a_{12} & \cdots & a_{1n}\\ a_{21} & 0 & \cdots & a_{2n}\\ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots\\ a_{n1} & a_{n2} & \cdots & 0\\ \end{bmatrix}R=‚é£‚é¢‚é¢‚é¢‚é¢‚é°‚Äã0a21‚Äã‚ãÆan1‚Äã‚Äãa12‚Äã0‚ãÆan2‚Äã‚Äã‚ãØ‚ãØ‚ã±‚ãØ‚Äãa1n‚Äãa2n‚Äã‚ãÆ0‚Äã‚é¶‚é•‚é•‚é•‚é•‚é§‚Äã

With relaxed Jaboci method, the iteration equation is expressed as
pl+1(t)=(1‚àíœâ)pl(t)+œâD‚àí1(b(t)‚àíRpl(t))\mathbf{p}^{l+1}(t)=(1-\omega)\mathbf{p}^l(t)+\omega\mathbf{D}^{-1}(\mathbf{b}(t)-\mathbf{R}\mathbf{p}^l(t))pl+1(t)=(1‚àíœâ)pl(t)+œâD‚àí1(b(t)‚àíRpl(t))

where lll denotes iteration index and œâ\omegaœâ denotes relaxation factor.

Actually, this relaxed Jacobi method is probably known as successive over relaxation method (SOR). For this method, the system itself should fullfill some conditions to ensure convergence like the coefficient matrix A\mathbf{A}A should be a strictly diagonally dominant matrix, etc. However in IISPH, these conditions are not considered rigorously. From my point of view, further provement should be added.

Each line (each particle) of this system of linear equations can be written as
‚àëjaijpj=œÅ0‚àíœÅiadv\sum_j a_{ij}p_j=\rho_0-\rho_i^{adv}j‚àë‚Äãaij‚Äãpj‚Äã=œÅ0‚Äã‚àíœÅiadv‚Äã

where aii=‚àëjmj(dii‚àídji)‚àáWija_{ii}=\sum_jm_j(\mathbf{d}_{ii}-\mathbf{d}_{ji})\nabla W_{ij}aii‚Äã=‚àëj‚Äãmj‚Äã(dii‚Äã‚àídji‚Äã)‚àáWij‚Äã and ‚àëj‚â†iaijpj=‚àëjmj(‚àëjdijpj‚àídjjpj‚àí‚àëk‚â†idjkpk)‚àáWij\sum_{j\neq i}a_{ij}p_j=\sum_jm_j(\sum_j\mathbf{d}_{ij}p_j-\mathbf{d}_{jj}p_j-\sum_{k\neq i}\mathbf{d}_{jk}p_k)\nabla W_{ij}‚àëjÓÄ†‚Äã=i‚Äãaij‚Äãpj‚Äã=‚àëj‚Äãmj‚Äã(‚àëj‚Äãdij‚Äãpj‚Äã‚àídjj‚Äãpj‚Äã‚àí‚àëkÓÄ†‚Äã=i‚Äãdjk‚Äãpk‚Äã)‚àáWij‚Äã can be derived from the key equation.
And the corresponding iteration equation is expressed as
pil+1=(1‚àíœâ)pil+œâœÅ0‚àíœÅiadv‚àí‚àëj‚â†iaijpjlaii=(1‚àíœâ)pil+œâaii(œÅ0‚àíœÅiadv‚àí‚àëjmj(‚àëjdijpjl‚àídjjpjl‚àí‚àëk‚â†idjkpkl)‚àáWij)\begin{aligned} p_i^{l+1}&=(1-\omega)p_i^l+\omega\frac{\rho_0-\rho_i^{adv}-\sum_{j\neq i}a_{ij}p_j^l}{a_{ii}}\\ &=(1-\omega)p_i^l+\frac{\omega}{a_{ii}}\left(\rho_0-\rho_i^{adv}-\sum_jm_j(\sum_j\mathbf{d}_{ij}p_j^l-\mathbf{d}_{jj}p_j^l-\sum_{k\neq i}\mathbf{d}_{jk}p_k^l)\nabla W_{ij}\right) \end{aligned}pil+1‚Äã‚Äã=(1‚àíœâ)pil‚Äã+œâaii‚ÄãœÅ0‚Äã‚àíœÅiadv‚Äã‚àí‚àëjÓÄ†‚Äã=i‚Äãaij‚Äãpjl‚Äã‚Äã=(1‚àíœâ)pil‚Äã+aii‚Äãœâ‚Äã‚éù‚éú‚éõ‚ÄãœÅ0‚Äã‚àíœÅiadv‚Äã‚àíj‚àë‚Äãmj‚Äã(j‚àë‚Äãdij‚Äãpjl‚Äã‚àídjj‚Äãpjl‚Äã‚àíkÓÄ†‚Äã=i‚àë‚Äãdjk‚Äãpkl‚Äã)‚àáWij‚Äã‚é†‚éü‚éû‚Äã‚Äã

This iteration will not terminate until the error is smaller than the given threshold.
Usually average density œÅavgl=‚àëiœÅiln\rho_{avg}^l=\frac{\sum_i \rho_i^l}{n}œÅavgl‚Äã=n‚àëi‚ÄãœÅil‚Äã‚Äã is predicted and used to compute residual.
œÅil=‚àëjmj(diipi+‚àëjdijpj‚àídjjpj‚àí‚àëkdjkpk)‚àáWij+œÅiadv\rho_i^l=\sum_jm_j(\mathbf{d}_{ii}p_i+\sum_j\mathbf{d}_{ij}p_j-\mathbf{d}_{jj}p_j-\sum_k\mathbf{d}_{jk}p_k)\nabla W_{ij}+\rho_i^{adv}œÅil‚Äã=j‚àë‚Äãmj‚Äã(dii‚Äãpi‚Äã+j‚àë‚Äãdij‚Äãpj‚Äã‚àídjj‚Äãpj‚Äã‚àík‚àë‚Äãdjk‚Äãpk‚Äã)‚àáWij‚Äã+œÅiadv‚Äã

Computation flow

Notes üê∂ about implementation:

  • The relaxation factor œâ\omegaœâ is difficult to determine in SOR. Usually trial and error are adopted to search for an optimal value regarding convergence.
    In IISPH, œâ=0.5\omega=0.5œâ=0.5 is adopted.
  • The initial pressure for the iteration is chosen as pi0=0.5pi(t‚àíŒît)p_i^0=0.5p_i(t-\Delta t)pi0‚Äã=0.5pi‚Äã(t‚àíŒît) for convergence.
  • For each particle, 7 scalars are computed and stored for 3D cases, namely aiia_{ii}aii‚Äã, dii\mathbf{d}_{ii}dii‚Äã and ‚àëjdijpjl\sum_j\mathbf{d}_{ij}p_j^l‚àëj‚Äãdij‚Äãpjl‚Äã in each iteration.
  • In the iteration equation, ‚àëk‚â†idjkpkl=‚àëkdjkpkl‚àídjipil\sum_{k\neq i}\mathbf{d}_{jk}p_k^l=\sum_k\mathbf{d}_{jk}p_k^l-\mathbf{d}_{ji}p_i^l‚àëkÓÄ†‚Äã=i‚Äãdjk‚Äãpkl‚Äã=‚àëk‚Äãdjk‚Äãpkl‚Äã‚àídji‚Äãpil‚Äã. Thus the term ‚àëkdjkpkl\sum_k\mathbf{d}_{jk}p_k^l‚àëk‚Äãdjk‚Äãpkl‚Äã can be accessed from particle without computation and only dji=‚àíŒît2miœÅi2‚àáWji\mathbf{d}_{ji}=-\Delta t^2\frac{m_i}{\rho_i^2}\nabla W_{ji}dji‚Äã=‚àíŒît2œÅi2‚Äãmi‚Äã‚Äã‚àáWji‚Äã should be computed.
  • In each iteration, pressure clamping is adopted, i.e. pil=max‚Å°(0,pil)p_i^l=\max(0,p_i^l)pil‚Äã=max(0,pil‚Äã).
  • During the process, particle mass mim_imi‚Äã and density œÅi\rho_iœÅi‚Äã keep unchanged. Whether predicted density should be used is unclear yet üò¢. Currently we choose to use œÅ0\rho_0œÅ0‚Äã during the whole process.

Divergence-free SPH (DFSPH)

NS equations

The incompressible, isothermal NS equations in Lagrangian coordinates is adopted.
DvDt=‚àí1œÅ‚àáp+ŒΩ‚àá2v+fœÅ\begin{aligned} \frac{D\mathbf{v}}{Dt}=-\frac{1}{\rho}\nabla p+\nu\nabla^2\mathbf{v}+\frac{\mathbf{f}}{\rho} \end{aligned}DtDv‚Äã=‚àíœÅ1‚Äã‚àáp+ŒΩ‚àá2v+œÅf‚Äã‚Äã

where œÅ,p,ŒΩ,v,f\rho,p,\nu,\mathbf{v},\mathbf{f}œÅ,p,ŒΩ,v,f denote density, pressure, kinematic viscosity, velocity and body force respectively.
This equation is based on the incompressibility assumption which is further maintained by the divergence-free velocity field condition.
DœÅDt=‚àíœÅ(‚àá‚ãÖv)=0‚áî‚àá‚ãÖv=0\begin{aligned} \frac{D\rho}{Dt}=-\rho(\nabla\cdot\mathbf{v})=0\Leftrightarrow\nabla\cdot\mathbf{v}=0 \end{aligned}DtDœÅ‚Äã=‚àíœÅ(‚àá‚ãÖv)=0‚áî‚àá‚ãÖv=0‚Äã

Divergence-free helps the enforcement of incompressibility. However, this is not enough since numerical errors may also cause fluid compressibility. To correct this, another condition needs to be fullfilled called constant density condition(commonly adopted by other common SPH methods like PCISPH) which is written as
œÅ‚àíœÅ0=0\rho-\rho_0=0œÅ‚àíœÅ0‚Äã=0

To deal with these 2 conditions, 2 pressure solvers (divergence-free solver + constant density solver) are adopted simultaneously to consider the divergence error and density error, respectively.

DFSPH cases

Hybrid Eulerian-Lagrangian

A fluid solver usually has 2 components:

  • Advection (evolving the fields)
  • Projection (enforcing incompressibility)

Eulerian grid is good at projection. (the grids are fixed and is suitable for searching for neighbors)
Lagrangian particles are good at advection. (just move the particles)

Combine them together where lagrangian particles store most of the information while eulerian grids are auxiliary.

Particle-in-cell (PIC/APIC/FLIP)

Use particles to carry information while grid as the framework.

P2G (particle to grid): transfer info from particles to grids using kernel functions (scatter).

G2P (grid to particle): transfer info from grid to particle (gather). [Angular momentum is not conserved.]

The particles interact with each other through grids.

ppp refers to particle and iii refers to grid.

üê∂ Energy dissipation (numerical diffusion) is obvious.
DOF is lost during G2P??.
DOFs of particles are lost in P2G=>G2P since typically the number of particles is much more than that of grids. In G2P, particle velocities are totally overwritten from grids thus some information of particles is lost. In FLIP, the particle velocities are incremented rather than overwritten.

2 solutions:

  • Transfer more information (rotation‚Ä¶): APIC,PolyPIC
    APIC[affine particle in cell] + bilibili video
    highly recommended for homework
    PolyPIC[polynomial particle in cell]
  • Transfer the delta: FLIP
    FLIP[fluid implicit particles]
    gather Œî\DeltaŒî of the physical quantities rather than themselves.
    PIC: vpt+1=gather(vit+1)v_p^{t+1}=gather(v_i^{t+1})vpt+1‚Äã=gather(vit+1‚Äã)
    FLIP: vpt+1=vpt+gather(vit+1‚àívit)v_p^{t+1}=v_p^t+gather(v_i^{t+1}-v_i^{t})vpt+1‚Äã=vpt‚Äã+gather(vit+1‚Äã‚àívit‚Äã)
    PIC is dissipative while FLIP is too noisy.
    Combine!! ‚áí\Rightarrow‚áí FLIP0.99=FLIP * 0.99+PIC * 0.01

To know more about APIC and its difference with PIC and FLIP, refer to An angular momentum conserving affine-particle-in-cell method (2017JCP).
PIC loses information during the mapping cycle P2G/G2P thus energy dissipation occurs.
FLIP transfers incremental information during cycle and preserves each particle‚Äôs original information to some extent however too much noise occurs.
APIC transfers more information like velocity gradient matrix thus the energy dissipation can be avoided to some extent.

PIC is almost never used in graphics.
APIC is suggested to start with.

Refer to pic_vs_apic codes to learn about the difference between PIC and APIC.

Interpolation function (kernel)

There are mainly 3 kinds of interpolation function used in PIC/APIC/MPM.

For both PIC and APIC, information transfer occurs between each particle (ppp) and its surrounding 4(linear)/9(quadratic)/16(cubic) grid points (iii). In the figures below, each red particle inside intersects with the surrounding blue grid points through the kernel function, which is defined on grid points.

During P2G and G2P cycle, the velocity is kind of smoothed and energy dissipation occurs.

Material Point Method (MPM)

No elements in MPM.
MPM particles => FEM quadrature points (Gaussian points)
MPM equations are derived using weak formulation.

Deformation gradient

X\mathbf{X}X: undeformed space.
x\mathbf{x}x: deformed space.
œï(X,t)\phi(\mathbf{X},t)œï(X,t): deformation map.
Their relationship is denoted with
x=œï(X,t)\mathbf{x}=\phi(\mathbf{X},t)x=œï(X,t)

For translation: x=X+vtn\mathbf{x}=\mathbf{X}+vt\mathbf{n}x=X+vtn
where n\mathbf{n}n is the moving direction.
For rotation: x=RX+b\mathbf{x}=\mathbf{R}\mathbf{X}+\mathbf{b}x=RX+b
where R\mathbf{R}R is the rotation matrix.(For 2D cases, R=[cos‚Å°Œ∏‚àísin‚Å°Œ∏sin‚Å°Œ∏cos‚Å°Œ∏]\mathbf{R}=\begin{bmatrix} \cos\theta & -\sin\theta\\ \sin\theta & \cos\theta \end{bmatrix}R=[cosŒ∏sinŒ∏‚Äã‚àísinŒ∏cosŒ∏‚Äã])

Deformation gradient:
F=‚àÇœï(X,t)‚àÇX=‚àÇx(X,t)‚àÇX\mathbf{F}=\frac{\partial\phi(\mathbf{X},t)}{\partial\mathbf{X}}=\frac{\partial\mathbf{x}(\mathbf{X},t)}{\partial\mathbf{X}}F=‚àÇX‚àÇœï(X,t)‚Äã=‚àÇX‚àÇx(X,t)‚Äã

Fij=‚àÇœïi‚àÇXj=‚àÇxi‚àÇXj,i,j=1,‚Ä¶,dF_{ij}=\frac{\partial\phi_i}{\partial X_j}=\frac{\partial x_i}{\partial X_j},\quad i,j=1,\dots,dFij‚Äã=‚àÇXj‚Äã‚àÇœïi‚Äã‚Äã=‚àÇXj‚Äã‚àÇxi‚Äã‚Äã,i,j=1,‚Ä¶,d

For rigid translation: F=Id√ód\mathbf{F}=\mathbf{I}_{d\times d}F=Id√ód‚Äã.
For rigid rotation: F=R\mathbf{F}=\mathbf{R}F=R.

The determinant of F\mathbf{F}F:
J=det‚Å°(F)J=\det(\mathbf{F})J=det(F)

This characterizes the infinitesimal volume change and represents the ratio of the infinitesimal volume of material in configuration Œ©t\Omega^tŒ©t to the original volume in Œ©0\Omega^0Œ©0.

  • J=1J=1J=1 means no volume change during the transformation. For rigid motions (rotations and translations), J=1J=1J=1.
  • J>1J>1J>1 means volume increase.
  • J<1J<1J<1 means volume decrease.
  • J=0J=0J=0 means volume becomes 0. In the real world this is impossible while numerically it is possible, eg. the material is so compressed that it becomes a plane or a line or a single volumeless point.
  • J<0J<0J<0 means the material is inverted. For a 2D triangle, this means one vertex passes through its opposing edge, resulting in negative area.
Push forward and pull back (lagrangian and eulerian function)

DefinitionÔºö
Push forward ‚áí\Rightarrow‚áí Eulerian (function of x\mathbf{x}x)
v(x,t)=V(œï‚àí1(x,t),t)v(\mathbf{x},t)=V(\phi^{-1}(\mathbf{x},t),t)v(x,t)=V(œï‚àí1(x,t),t)

where vvv is the push forward of VVV.
Pull back ‚áí\Rightarrow‚áí Lagrangian (function of X\mathbf{X}X)
V(X,t)=v(œï(X,t),t)V(\mathbf{X},t)=v(\phi(\mathbf{X},t),t)V(X,t)=v(œï(X,t),t)

where VVV is the pull back of vvv.

Material derivative:
For a general Eulerian function f(‚ãÖ,t)f(\cdot,t)f(‚ãÖ,t),
DDtf(x,t)=‚àÇf(x,t)‚àÇt+‚àÇf(x,t)‚àÇxjvj(x,t)\frac{D}{Dt}f(\mathbf{x},t)=\frac{\partial f(\mathbf{x},t)}{\partial t}+\frac{\partial f(\mathbf{x},t)}{\partial x_j}v_j(\mathbf{x},t)DtD‚Äãf(x,t)=‚àÇt‚àÇf(x,t)‚Äã+‚àÇxj‚Äã‚àÇf(x,t)‚Äãvj‚Äã(x,t)

where Eulerian DDtf(x,t)\frac{D}{Dt}f(\mathbf{x},t)DtD‚Äãf(x,t) is the push forward of ‚àÇF‚àÇt\frac{\partial F}{\partial t}‚àÇt‚àÇF‚Äã and FFF is a Lagrangian function.

Volume and area change:
Volume:
v=JdVv=JdVv=JdV

where J=det‚Å°(F)J=\det(\mathbf{F})J=det(F), v‚áíxv\Rightarrow xv‚áíx(Eulerian), V‚áíXV\Rightarrow XV‚áíX(Lagrangian).
Based on this we have
‚à´Btg(x)dx=‚à´B0G(X)J(X,t)dX\int_{B^t}g(\mathbf{x})d\mathbf{x}=\int_{B^0}G(\mathbf{X})J(\mathbf{X},t)d\mathbf{X}‚à´Bt‚Äãg(x)dx=‚à´B0‚ÄãG(X)J(X,t)dX

where ggg is the push forward of GGG.

Area:
ds=F‚àíTJdSornds=F‚àíTJNdSd\mathbf{s}=\mathbf{F}^{-T}Jd\mathbf{S}\quad or\quad \mathbf{n}ds=\mathbf{F}^{-T}J\mathbf{N}dSds=F‚àíTJdSornds=F‚àíTJNdS

where sss and SSS are tiny areas.
Based on this we have
‚à´‚àÇBth(x,t)‚ãÖn(x)ds(x)=‚à´‚àÇB0H(X)‚ãÖF‚àíT(X,t)N(X)J(X,t)dS(X)\int_{\partial B^t}h(\mathbf{x},t)\cdot\mathbf{n}(\mathbf{x})ds(\mathbf{x})=\int_{\partial B^0}H(\mathbf{X})\cdot\mathbf{F}^{-T}(\mathbf{X},t)N(\mathbf{X})J(\mathbf{X},t)dS(\mathbf{X})‚à´‚àÇBt‚Äãh(x,t)‚ãÖn(x)ds(x)=‚à´‚àÇB0‚ÄãH(X)‚ãÖF‚àíT(X,t)N(X)J(X,t)dS(X)

Constitutive model

For hyperelastic material:
PK1 stress (First Piola-Kirchoff stress) P\mathbf{P}P can be derived from
P=‚àÇœà(F)‚àÇF\mathbf{P}=\frac{\partial\psi(\mathbf{F})}{\partial\mathbf{F}}P=‚àÇF‚àÇœà(F)‚Äã

where œà\psiœà is the elastic energy density function (scalar function) and F\mathbf{F}F is the deformation gradient.
With index notation,
Pij=‚àÇœà‚àÇFijP_{ij}=\frac{\partial\psi}{\partial{F_{ij}}}Pij‚Äã=‚àÇFij‚Äã‚àÇœà‚Äã

The Cauchy stress can be obtained from
œÉ=1JPFT=1det‚Å°(F)‚àÇœà‚àÇFFT\mathbf{\sigma}=\frac{1}{J}\mathbf{P}\mathbf{F}^T=\frac{1}{\det(\mathbf{F})}\frac{\partial\psi}{\partial\mathbf{F}}\mathbf{F}^TœÉ=J1‚ÄãPFT=det(F)1‚Äã‚àÇF‚àÇœà‚ÄãFT

2 common hyperelastic materials: Neo-Hookean and Fixed Corotated.
Refer to elastic solids.

Governing equations

Conservation of mass + Conservation of momentum

Determinant differentiation rule:
For an invertible matrix A\mathbf{A}A,
‚àÇdet‚Å°(A)‚àÇA=det‚Å°(A)A‚àíT\frac{\partial\det(\mathbf{A})}{\partial \mathbf{A}}=\det(\mathbf{A}) \mathbf{A}^{-T}‚àÇA‚àÇdet(A)‚Äã=det(A)A‚àíT
This leads to the commonly used rule:
‚àÇdet‚Å°(F)‚àÇF=det‚Å°(F)F‚àíT\frac{\partial\det(\mathbf{F})}{\partial \mathbf{F}}=\det(\mathbf{F}) \mathbf{F}^{-T}‚àÇF‚àÇdet(F)‚Äã=det(F)F‚àíT

Weak form of force balance
Mainly based on conservation of momentum.
(Actually momentum theorem rather than conservation).
mŒîv=FŒît‚áîmŒîvŒît=Fm\Delta\mathbf{v}=\mathbf{F}\Delta t\Leftrightarrow \frac{m\Delta\mathbf{v}}{\Delta t}=\mathbf{F}mŒîv=FŒît‚áîŒîtmŒîv‚Äã=F
Lagrangian view:
‚à´Œ©0Qi(X,t)R(X,0)Ai(X,t)dX=‚à´‚àÇŒ©0QiTids(X)‚àí‚à´Œ©0Qi,jPijdX\int_{\Omega^0}Q_i(\mathbf{X},t)R(\mathbf{X},0)A_i(\mathbf{X},t)d\mathbf{X}=\int_{\partial\Omega^0}Q_iT_ids(\mathbf{X})-\int_{\Omega^0}Q_{i,j}P_{ij}d\mathbf{X}‚à´Œ©0‚ÄãQi‚Äã(X,t)R(X,0)Ai‚Äã(X,t)dX=‚à´‚àÇŒ©0‚ÄãQi‚ÄãTi‚Äãds(X)‚àí‚à´Œ©0‚ÄãQi,j‚ÄãPij‚ÄãdX

Eulerian view:
‚à´Œ©tqi(x,t)œÅ(x,t)ai(x,t)dx=‚à´‚àÇŒ©tqitids(x)‚àí‚à´Œ©tqi,kœÉikdx\int_{\Omega^t}q_i(\mathbf{x},t)\rho(\mathbf{x},t)a_i(\mathbf{x},t)d\mathbf{x}=\int_{\partial\Omega^t}q_it_ids(\mathbf{x})-\int_{\Omega^t}q_{i,k}\sigma_{ik}d\mathbf{x}‚à´Œ©t‚Äãqi‚Äã(x,t)œÅ(x,t)ai‚Äã(x,t)dx=‚à´‚àÇŒ©t‚Äãqi‚Äãti‚Äãds(x)‚àí‚à´Œ©t‚Äãqi,k‚ÄãœÉik‚Äãdx

Here i,j,ki,j,ki,j,k are component index for dimensions, tit_iti‚Äã is the iii component of boundary force t\mathbf{t}t.
LHS (left-hand side) is some kind of momentum change rate over time while RHS is some kind of net force ignoring the external force.

Material particles

Momentum and mass are transfered between grid and particle through interpolation function.

Interpolation function

The interpolation function is defined over the Eulerian grid rather than on the material particles like the kernel of SPH particles.
wip=Ni(xp)=N(1h(xp‚àíxi))N(1h(yp‚àíyi))N(1h(zp‚àízi))w_{ip}=N_\mathbf{i}(\mathbf{x}_p)=N(\frac{1}{h}(x_p-x_i))N(\frac{1}{h}(y_p-y_i))N(\frac{1}{h}(z_p-z_i))wip‚Äã=Ni‚Äã(xp‚Äã)=N(h1‚Äã(xp‚Äã‚àíxi‚Äã))N(h1‚Äã(yp‚Äã‚àíyi‚Äã))N(h1‚Äã(zp‚Äã‚àízi‚Äã))

‚àáwip=‚àáNi(xp)=(1hN‚Ä≤(1h(xp‚àíxi))N(1h(yp‚àíyi))N(1h(zp‚àízi))N(1h(xp‚àíxi))1hN‚Ä≤(1h(yp‚àíyi))N(1h(zp‚àízi))N(1h(xp‚àíxi))N(1h(yp‚àíyi))1hN‚Ä≤(1h(zp‚àízi)))\nabla w_{ip}=\nabla N_{\mathbf{i}}(\mathbf{x}_p)= \begin{pmatrix} \frac{1}{h}N'(\frac{1}{h}(x_p-x_i))N(\frac{1}{h}(y_p-y_i))N(\frac{1}{h}(z_p-z_i))\\ N(\frac{1}{h}(x_p-x_i))\frac{1}{h}N'(\frac{1}{h}(y_p-y_i))N(\frac{1}{h}(z_p-z_i))\\ N(\frac{1}{h}(x_p-x_i))N(\frac{1}{h}(y_p-y_i))\frac{1}{h}N'(\frac{1}{h}(z_p-z_i))\\ \end{pmatrix}‚àáwip‚Äã=‚àáNi‚Äã(xp‚Äã)=‚éù‚éú‚éõ‚Äãh1‚ÄãN‚Ä≤(h1‚Äã(xp‚Äã‚àíxi‚Äã))N(h1‚Äã(yp‚Äã‚àíyi‚Äã))N(h1‚Äã(zp‚Äã‚àízi‚Äã))N(h1‚Äã(xp‚Äã‚àíxi‚Äã))h1‚ÄãN‚Ä≤(h1‚Äã(yp‚Äã‚àíyi‚Äã))N(h1‚Äã(zp‚Äã‚àízi‚Äã))N(h1‚Äã(xp‚Äã‚àíxi‚Äã))N(h1‚Äã(yp‚Äã‚àíyi‚Äã))h1‚ÄãN‚Ä≤(h1‚Äã(zp‚Äã‚àízi‚Äã))‚Äã‚é†‚éü‚éû‚Äã

Refer to interpolation function for plots of linear/quadratic/cubic functions.

Lagrangian/Eulerian mass

P2G mass transfer:
mi=‚àëpmpNi(xp)m_i=\sum_p m_p N_i(\mathbf{x}_p)mi‚Äã=p‚àë‚Äãmp‚ÄãNi‚Äã(xp‚Äã)

This ensures the conservation of mass through the partition of unity assumption on interpolation function ‚àëiNi(xp)=1\sum_i N_i(\mathbf{x}_p)=1‚àëi‚ÄãNi‚Äã(xp‚Äã)=1:
‚àëimi=‚àëi‚àëpmpNi(xp)=‚àëpmp‚àëiNi(xp)=‚àëpmp\sum_i m_i = \sum_i\sum_p m_p N_i(\mathbf{x}_p) = \sum_p m_p \sum_i N_i(\mathbf{x}_p) = \sum_p m_pi‚àë‚Äãmi‚Äã=i‚àë‚Äãp‚àë‚Äãmp‚ÄãNi‚Äã(xp‚Äã)=p‚àë‚Äãmp‚Äãi‚àë‚ÄãNi‚Äã(xp‚Äã)=p‚àë‚Äãmp‚Äã

No G2P mass transfer since the particle mass never changes.

Lagrangian/Eulerian momentum

P2G momentum transfer:
(mv)i=‚àëpmpvpNi(xp)vi=(mv)imi\begin{aligned} (m\mathbf{v})_i &= \sum_p m_p \mathbf{v}_p N_i(\mathbf{x}_p)\\ \mathbf{v}_i &= \frac{(m\mathbf{v})_i}{m_i} \end{aligned}(mv)i‚Äãvi‚Äã‚Äã=p‚àë‚Äãmp‚Äãvp‚ÄãNi‚Äã(xp‚Äã)=mi‚Äã(mv)i‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã

Since ‚àëimvi=‚àëi(mv)i=‚àëp‚àëimpvpNi(xp)=‚àëpmpvp\sum_i m\mathbf{v}_i = \sum_i(m\mathbf{v})_i=\sum_p\sum_i m_p \mathbf{v}_p N_i(\mathbf{x}_p)=\sum_p m_p \mathbf{v}_p‚àëi‚Äãmvi‚Äã=‚àëi‚Äã(mv)i‚Äã=‚àëp‚Äã‚àëi‚Äãmp‚Äãvp‚ÄãNi‚Äã(xp‚Äã)=‚àëp‚Äãmp‚Äãvp‚Äã, momentum is conserved in P2G transfer.

G2P velocity transfer:
Since particle mass keeps unchanged, only velocity is transfered in G2P rather than momentum.
vp=‚àëiviNi(xp)\mathbf{v}_p = \sum_i\mathbf{v}_iN_i(\mathbf{x}_p)vp‚Äã=i‚àë‚Äãvi‚ÄãNi‚Äã(xp‚Äã)

Since ‚àëpmpvp=‚àëpmp‚àëiviNi(xp)=‚àëivi‚àëpmpNi(xp)=‚àëimivi\sum_p m_p\mathbf{v}_p=\sum_p m_p\sum_i\mathbf{v}_iN_i(\mathbf{x}_p) = \sum_i\mathbf{v}_i\sum_pm_pN_i(\mathbf{x}_p)=\sum_i m_i \mathbf{v}_i‚àëp‚Äãmp‚Äãvp‚Äã=‚àëp‚Äãmp‚Äã‚àëi‚Äãvi‚ÄãNi‚Äã(xp‚Äã)=‚àëi‚Äãvi‚Äã‚àëp‚Äãmp‚ÄãNi‚Äã(xp‚Äã)=‚àëi‚Äãmi‚Äãvi‚Äã, momentum is conserved in G2P transfer.

Noteüê∑: Unlike mass, total momentum keeps changing in the system. This is achieved in Grid operations through introducing impulse. Details will be given later.

Discretization

In this part, i,j,ki,j,ki,j,k denote grid nodes, Œ±,Œ≤,Œ≥\alpha,\beta,\gammaŒ±,Œ≤,Œ≥ denote dimensional components.
For instance, qiŒ±q_{i\alpha}qiŒ±‚Äã means the Œ±\alphaŒ± component of the vector quantity q\mathbf{q}q that is stored at node iii.

Discrete time

By introducing aŒ±(x,tn)=1Œît(vŒ±n+1(x)‚àívŒ±n(x))a_{\alpha}(\mathbf{x},t^n)=\frac{1}{\Delta t}(v_\alpha^{n+1}(\mathbf{x})-v_\alpha^n(\mathbf{x}))aŒ±‚Äã(x,tn)=Œît1‚Äã(vŒ±n+1‚Äã(x)‚àívŒ±n‚Äã(x)) into the weak form governing equation, we have
1Œît‚à´Œ©tnqŒ±(x,tn)œÅ(x,tn)(vŒ±n+1(x)‚àívŒ±n(x))dx=‚à´‚àÇŒ©tnqŒ±(x,tn)tŒ±(x,tn)ds(x)‚àí‚à´Œ©tnqŒ±,Œ≤(x,tn)œÉŒ±Œ≤(x,tn)dx\begin{aligned} &\frac{1}{\Delta t}\int_{\Omega^{t^n}} q_\alpha(\mathbf{x},t^n)\rho(\mathbf{x},t^n)(v_\alpha^{n+1}(\mathbf{x})-v_\alpha^n(\mathbf{x}))d\mathbf{x}\\&=\int_{\partial\Omega^{t^n}}q_\alpha(\mathbf{x},t^n)t_\alpha(\mathbf{x},t^n)ds(\mathbf{x})-\int_{\Omega^{t^n}}q_{\alpha,\beta}(\mathbf{x},t^n)\sigma_{\alpha\beta}(\mathbf{x},t^n)d\mathbf{x} \end{aligned}‚ÄãŒît1‚Äã‚à´Œ©tn‚ÄãqŒ±‚Äã(x,tn)œÅ(x,tn)(vŒ±n+1‚Äã(x)‚àívŒ±n‚Äã(x))dx=‚à´‚àÇŒ©tn‚ÄãqŒ±‚Äã(x,tn)tŒ±‚Äã(x,tn)ds(x)‚àí‚à´Œ©tn‚ÄãqŒ±,Œ≤‚Äã(x,tn)œÉŒ±Œ≤‚Äã(x,tn)dx‚Äã

Discrete space

Further discretize the weak form force balance equation over space, we have
((mv)iŒ±n+1‚àí(mv)iŒ±n)Œît=‚à´‚àÇŒ©tnNi(x)tŒ±(x,tn)ds(x)‚àí‚à´Œ©tnNi,Œ≤(x)œÉŒ±Œ≤(x,tn)dx\frac{((mv)_{i\alpha}^{n+1}-(mv)_{i\alpha}^{n})}{\Delta t}=\int_{\partial\Omega^{t^n}}N_i(\mathbf{x})t_\alpha(\mathbf{x},t^n)ds(\mathbf{x})-\int_{\Omega^{t^n}}N_{i,\beta}(\mathbf{x})\sigma_{\alpha\beta}(\mathbf{x},t^n)d\mathbf{x}Œît((mv)iŒ±n+1‚Äã‚àí(mv)iŒ±n‚Äã)‚Äã=‚à´‚àÇŒ©tn‚ÄãNi‚Äã(x)tŒ±‚Äã(x,tn)ds(x)‚àí‚à´Œ©tn‚ÄãNi,Œ≤‚Äã(x)œÉŒ±Œ≤‚Äã(x,tn)dx

Assuming we have an estimate of the Cauchy stress œÉpn=œÉ(xpn,tn)\mathbf{\sigma}_p^n=\mathbf{\sigma}(\mathbf{x}_p^n,t^n)œÉpn‚Äã=œÉ(xpn‚Äã,tn) at each Lagrangian particle xpn\mathbf{x}_p^nxpn‚Äã, force on the Eulerian grid node iii can be written as
‚à´Œ©tnNi,Œ≤(x)œÉŒ±Œ≤(x,tn)dx‚âà‚àëpœÉp‚ÄâŒ±Œ≤nNi,Œ≤(xpn)Vpn\int_{\Omega^{t^n}}N_{i,\beta}(\mathbf{x})\sigma_{\alpha\beta}(\mathbf{x},t^n)d\mathbf{x}\approx\sum_p\sigma_{p\,\alpha\beta}^nN_{i,\beta}(\mathbf{x}_p^n)V_p^n‚à´Œ©tn‚ÄãNi,Œ≤‚Äã(x)œÉŒ±Œ≤‚Äã(x,tn)dx‚âàp‚àë‚ÄãœÉpŒ±Œ≤n‚ÄãNi,Œ≤‚Äã(xpn‚Äã)Vpn‚Äã

where VpnV_p^nVpn‚Äã is the volume particle ppp occupied at time tnt^ntn.

Estimating volume

There are mainly 2 methods to estimate.

  • Estimation based on grid density
    mp‚âàR(Xp,0)Vp0‚âàœÅ(xpn,tn)VpnœÅ(xpn,tn)‚âà‚àëiœÅinNi(xpn)œÅin=minŒîxd\begin{aligned} &m_p\approx R(\mathbf{X}_p,0)V_p^0\approx \rho(\mathbf{x}_p^n,t^n)V_p^n\\ &\rho(\mathbf{x}_p^n,t^n)\approx\sum_i\rho_i^nN_i(\mathbf{x}_p^n)\\ &\rho_i^n=\frac{m_i^n}{\Delta x^d}\\ \end{aligned}‚Äãmp‚Äã‚âàR(Xp‚Äã,0)Vp0‚Äã‚âàœÅ(xpn‚Äã,tn)Vpn‚ÄãœÅ(xpn‚Äã,tn)‚âài‚àë‚ÄãœÅin‚ÄãNi‚Äã(xpn‚Äã)œÅin‚Äã=Œîxdmin‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã

    where Œîx\Delta xŒîx is the size of each Eulerian grid and ddd is the dimension.
    Since grid density is easy to compute, the volume can be estimated
    Vpn‚âàmpœÅ(xpn,tn)‚âàmp‚àëiminŒîxdNi(xpn)=mpŒîxd‚àëiminNi(xpn)V_p^n\approx\frac{m_p}{\rho(\mathbf{x}_p^n,t^n)}\approx\frac{m_p}{\sum_i\frac{m_i^n}{\Delta x^d}N_i(\mathbf{x}_p^n)}=\frac{m_p\Delta x^d}{\sum_i m_i^n N_i(\mathbf{x}_p^n)}Vpn‚Äã‚âàœÅ(xpn‚Äã,tn)mp‚Äã‚Äã‚âà‚àëi‚ÄãŒîxdmin‚Äã‚ÄãNi‚Äã(xpn‚Äã)mp‚Äã‚Äã=‚àëi‚Äãmin‚ÄãNi‚Äã(xpn‚Äã)mp‚ÄãŒîxd‚Äã

  • Estimation based on deformation gradient
    Typically we have
    Vpn‚âàJpnVp0V_p^n \approx J_p^n V_p^0Vpn‚Äã‚âàJpn‚ÄãVp0‚Äã

    where Jpn=det‚Å°(Fpn)J_p^n = \det(\mathbf{F}_p^n)Jpn‚Äã=det(Fpn‚Äã).

Baed on the second method and substituting Cauchy stress œÉ\boldsymbol{\sigma}œÉ with 1JPFT\frac{1}{J}\mathbf{P}\mathbf{F}^TJ1‚ÄãPFT, the force on the Eulerian grid node iii can be further rewritten as
‚àëpœÉp‚ÄâŒ±Œ≤nNi,Œ≤(xpn)Vpn=‚àëp1JpnPp‚ÄâŒ±Œ≥nFp‚ÄâŒ≤Œ≥nNi,Œ≤(xpn)Vp0Jpn=‚àëpPp‚ÄâŒ±Œ≥nFp‚ÄâŒ≤Œ≥nNi,Œ≤(xpn)Vp0\sum_p\sigma_{p\,\alpha\beta}^n N_{i,\beta}(\mathbf{x}_p^n)V_p^n=\sum_p\frac{1}{J_p^n}P_{p\,\alpha\gamma}^n F_{p\,\beta\gamma}^n N_{i,\beta}(\mathbf{x}_p^n)V_p^0J_p^n=\sum_p P_{p\,\alpha\gamma}^n F_{p\,\beta\gamma}^n N_{i,\beta}(\mathbf{x}_p^n)V_p^0p‚àë‚ÄãœÉpŒ±Œ≤n‚ÄãNi,Œ≤‚Äã(xpn‚Äã)Vpn‚Äã=p‚àë‚ÄãJpn‚Äã1‚ÄãPpŒ±Œ≥n‚ÄãFpŒ≤Œ≥n‚ÄãNi,Œ≤‚Äã(xpn‚Äã)Vp0‚ÄãJpn‚Äã=p‚àë‚ÄãPpŒ±Œ≥n‚ÄãFpŒ≤Œ≥n‚ÄãNi,Œ≤‚Äã(xpn‚Äã)Vp0‚Äã

Now the discretized weak form force balance equation can be written as
((mv)iŒ±n+1‚àí(mv)iŒ±n)Œît=‚à´‚àÇŒ©tnNi(x)tŒ±(x,tn)ds(x)‚àí‚àëpPp‚ÄâŒ±Œ≥nFp‚ÄâŒ≤Œ≥nNi,Œ≤(xpn)Vp0\frac{((mv)_{i\alpha}^{n+1}-(mv)_{i\alpha}^{n})}{\Delta t}=\int_{\partial\Omega^{t^n}}N_i(\mathbf{x})t_\alpha(\mathbf{x},t^n)ds(\mathbf{x})-\sum_p P_{p\,\alpha\gamma}^n F_{p\,\beta\gamma}^n N_{i,\beta}(\mathbf{x}_p^n)V_p^0Œît((mv)iŒ±n+1‚Äã‚àí(mv)iŒ±n‚Äã)‚Äã=‚à´‚àÇŒ©tn‚ÄãNi‚Äã(x)tŒ±‚Äã(x,tn)ds(x)‚àíp‚àë‚ÄãPpŒ±Œ≥n‚ÄãFpŒ≤Œ≥n‚ÄãNi,Œ≤‚Äã(xpn‚Äã)Vp0‚Äã

Note: Different constitutive models are introduced to the scheme by expressing the PK1 stress P\mathbf{P}P in different ways.
In computer graphics, hyperelastic material is preferred since it has a well defined potential energy œà\psiœà and the PK1 stress can be easily computed as P=‚àÇœà‚àÇF\mathbf{P}=\frac{\partial\psi}{\partial\mathbf{F}}P=‚àÇF‚àÇœà‚Äã.

Deformation gradient evolution

‚àÇ‚àÇtF(Xp,tn+1)‚âàFpn+1‚àíFpnŒîtFpn+1=Fpn+Œît‚àÇ‚àÇtF(Xp,tn+1)\begin{aligned} &\frac{\partial}{\partial t}\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{X}_p,t^{n+1})\approx\frac{\mathbf{F}_p^{n+1}-\mathbf{F}_p^n}{\Delta t}\\ &\mathbf{F}_p^{n+1}=\mathbf{F}_p^n+\Delta t \frac{\partial}{\partial t}\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{X}_p,t^{n+1}) \end{aligned}‚Äã‚àÇt‚àÇ‚ÄãF(Xp‚Äã,tn+1)‚âàŒîtFpn+1‚Äã‚àíFpn‚Äã‚ÄãFpn+1‚Äã=Fpn‚Äã+Œît‚àÇt‚àÇ‚ÄãF(Xp‚Äã,tn+1)‚Äã

where F(Xp,tn+1)\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{X}_p,t^{n+1})F(Xp‚Äã,tn+1) is simplified as Fpn+1\mathbf{F}_p^{n+1}Fpn+1‚Äã.
Also we have
‚àÇ‚àÇtF(X,tn+1)=‚àÇV‚àÇX(X,tn+1)=‚àÇvn+1(x)‚àÇxF(X,tn)vn+1(x)=‚àëivin+1Ni(x)‚àÇvn+1(x)‚àÇx=‚àëivin+1(‚àÇNi(x)‚àÇx)T\begin{aligned} &\frac{\partial}{\partial t}\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{X},t^{n+1})=\frac{\partial\mathbf{V}}{\partial\mathbf{X}}(\mathbf{X},t^{n+1})=\frac{\partial \mathbf{v}^{n+1}(\mathbf{x})}{\partial\mathbf{x}}\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{X},t^n)\\ &\mathbf{v}^{n+1}(\mathbf{x})=\sum_i \mathbf{v}_i^{n+1}N_i(\mathbf{x})\\ &\frac{\partial \mathbf{v}^{n+1}(\mathbf{x})}{\partial\mathbf{x}}=\sum_i \mathbf{v}_i^{n+1}(\frac{\partial N_i(\mathbf{x})}{\partial\mathbf{x}})^T \end{aligned}‚Äã‚àÇt‚àÇ‚ÄãF(X,tn+1)=‚àÇX‚àÇV‚Äã(X,tn+1)=‚àÇx‚àÇvn+1(x)‚ÄãF(X,tn)vn+1(x)=i‚àë‚Äãvin+1‚ÄãNi‚Äã(x)‚àÇx‚àÇvn+1(x)‚Äã=i‚àë‚Äãvin+1‚Äã(‚àÇx‚àÇNi‚Äã(x)‚Äã)T‚Äã

Combining them together we have
Fpn+1=(I+Œît‚àëivin+1(‚àÇNi(xpn)‚àÇx)T)Fpn\mathbf{F}_p^{n+1}=(\mathbf{I}+\Delta t\sum_i \mathbf{v}_i^{n+1}(\frac{\partial N_i(\mathbf{x}_p^n)}{\partial\mathbf{x}})^T)\mathbf{F}_p^nFpn+1‚Äã=(I+Œîti‚àë‚Äãvin+1‚Äã(‚àÇx‚àÇNi‚Äã(xpn‚Äã)‚Äã)T)Fpn‚Äã

Based on this, Fpn+1\mathbf{F}_p^{n+1}Fpn+1‚Äã can be obtained given vin+1\mathbf{v}_i^{n+1}vin+1‚Äã and Fpn\mathbf{F}_p^nFpn‚Äã at each particle.

Forces as energy gradient

Force on the Eulerian grid node (derived from weak form governing equation) can also be derived from energy gradient for hyperelastic material.

Explicit time integration scheme
  • Particle to grid (P2G)
    • (mv)in+1=‚àëpwip(mpvpn+Bp(Dp)‚àí1(xi‚àíxp))(m\mathbf{v})_i^{n+1}=\sum_pw_{ip}(m_p\mathbf{v}_p^n+\mathbf{B}_p(\mathbf{D}_p)^{-1}(\mathbf{x}_i-\mathbf{x}_p))(mv)in+1‚Äã=‚àëp‚Äãwip‚Äã(mp‚Äãvpn‚Äã+Bp‚Äã(Dp‚Äã)‚àí1(xi‚Äã‚àíxp‚Äã)) (Grid momentum)

      This is from APIC.
      Cp=Bp(Dp)‚àí1Dp=‚àëiwip(xi‚àíxp)(xi‚àíxp)TBp=‚àëiwipvi(xi‚àíxp)T\begin{aligned}\mathbf{C}_p &= \mathbf{B}_p (\mathbf{D}_p)^{-1}\\\mathbf{D}_p &= \sum_i w_{ip} (\mathbf{x}_i-\mathbf{x}_p)(\mathbf{x}_i-\mathbf{x}_p)^T\\ \mathbf{B}_p &= \sum_i w_{ip} \mathbf{v}_i (\mathbf{x}_i-\mathbf{x}_p)^T \end{aligned}Cp‚ÄãDp‚ÄãBp‚Äã‚Äã=Bp‚Äã(Dp‚Äã)‚àí1=i‚àë‚Äãwip‚Äã(xi‚Äã‚àíxp‚Äã)(xi‚Äã‚àíxp‚Äã)T=i‚àë‚Äãwip‚Äãvi‚Äã(xi‚Äã‚àíxp‚Äã)T‚Äã

      For quadratic kernel, Dp=Œîx24I\mathbf{D}_p=\frac{\Delta x^2}{4}\mathbf{I}Dp‚Äã=4Œîx2‚ÄãI and Cp=4Œîx2‚àëiwipvi(xi‚àíxp)T\mathbf{C}_p=\frac{4}{{\Delta x}^2}\sum_i w_{ip} \mathbf{v}_i (\mathbf{x}_i-\mathbf{x}_p)^TCp‚Äã=Œîx24‚Äã‚àëi‚Äãwip‚Äãvi‚Äã(xi‚Äã‚àíxp‚Äã)T;
      For cubic kernel, Dp=Œîx23I\mathbf{D}_p=\frac{\Delta x^2}{3}\mathbf{I}Dp‚Äã=3Œîx2‚ÄãI and Cp=3Œîx2‚àëiwipvi(xi‚àíxp)T\mathbf{C}_p=\frac{3}{{\Delta x}^2}\sum_i w_{ip} \mathbf{v}_i (\mathbf{x}_i-\mathbf{x}_p)^TCp‚Äã=Œîx23‚Äã‚àëi‚Äãwip‚Äãvi‚Äã(xi‚Äã‚àíxp‚Äã)T;
      For linear kernel, Cp=‚àëivi(‚àÇNi‚àÇx(xp))T=‚àëivi(‚àáwip)T\mathbf{C}_p=\sum_i\mathbf{v}_i(\frac{\partial N_i}{\partial\mathbf{x}}(\mathbf{x}_p))^T=\sum_i\mathbf{v}_i(\nabla w_{ip})^TCp‚Äã=‚àëi‚Äãvi‚Äã(‚àÇx‚àÇNi‚Äã‚Äã(xp‚Äã))T=‚àëi‚Äãvi‚Äã(‚àáwip‚Äã)T

    • min+1=‚àëpmpwipm_i^{n+1}=\sum_p m_p w_{ip}min+1‚Äã=‚àëp‚Äãmp‚Äãwip‚Äã (Grid mass)
  • Grid operations
    • v^in+1=(mv)in+1mi\hat\mathbf{v}_i^{n+1}=\frac{(m\mathbf{v})_i^{n+1}}{m_i}v^in+1‚Äã=mi‚Äã(mv)in+1‚Äã‚Äã (Grid velocity)
    • Only label the grid nodes with nonzero masses as solver unknowns. (Identify grid DOF)
    • fin=‚àí‚àëpPpnFpnT‚àáwipnVp0\mathbf{f}_i^n=-\sum_p \mathbf{P}_p^n {\mathbf{F}_p^n}^T \nabla w_{ip}^n V_p^0fin‚Äã=‚àí‚àëp‚ÄãPpn‚ÄãFpn‚ÄãT‚àáwipn‚ÄãVp0‚Äã or fin=‚àí‚àëpœÉpn‚àáwipnVpn\mathbf{f}_i^n=-\sum_p\boldsymbol{\sigma}_p^n \nabla w_{ip}^n V_p^nfin‚Äã=‚àí‚àëp‚ÄãœÉpn‚Äã‚àáwipn‚ÄãVpn‚Äã (Compute grid forces)

      The 2 formulas can be transferred via œÉ=1JPFT\boldsymbol{\sigma}=\frac{1}{J}\mathbf{P}\mathbf{F}^TœÉ=J1‚ÄãPFT and Vpn=JVp0V_p^n=JV_p^0Vpn‚Äã=JVp0‚Äã.
      For hyperelastic material, P\mathbf{P}P is easily obtained by P=‚àÇœàp‚àÇFp\mathbf{P}=\frac{\partial\psi_p}{\partial\mathbf{F}_p}P=‚àÇFp‚Äã‚àÇœàp‚Äã‚Äã thus the 1st formula is used.

    • vin+1=v^in+1+Œîtfinmi\mathbf{v}_i^{n+1}=\hat\mathbf{v}_i^{n+1}+\Delta t\frac{\mathbf{f} _i^n}{m_i}vin+1‚Äã=v^in+1‚Äã+Œîtmi‚Äãfin‚Äã‚Äã (Grid velocity update)

      Boundary conditions and collision objects are also taken into account in this part.

  • Grid to particle (G2P)
    • Fpn+1=(I+Œît‚àëivin+1(‚àáwipn)T)Fpn\mathbf{F}_p^{n+1}=(\mathbf{I}+\Delta t\sum_i \mathbf{v}_i^{n+1}(\nabla w_{ip}^n)^T)\mathbf{F}_p^nFpn+1‚Äã=(I+Œît‚àëi‚Äãvin+1‚Äã(‚àáwipn‚Äã)T)Fpn‚Äã (Particle deformation gradient update)

      Gradient of interpolation function is needed here. ‚àáwip=‚àÇNi(xp)‚àÇx\nabla w_{ip} = \frac{\partial N_i(\mathbf{x}_p)}{\partial\mathbf{x}}‚àáwip‚Äã=‚àÇx‚àÇNi‚Äã(xp‚Äã)‚Äã is a ddd dimensional vector.

    • Dp=‚àëiwip(xi‚àíxp)(xi‚àíxp)T\mathbf{D}_p = \sum_i w_{ip} (\mathbf{x}_i-\mathbf{x}_p)(\mathbf{x}_i-\mathbf{x}_p)^TDp‚Äã=‚àëi‚Äãwip‚Äã(xi‚Äã‚àíxp‚Äã)(xi‚Äã‚àíxp‚Äã)T and Bp=‚àëiwipvi(xi‚àíxp)T\mathbf{B}_p = \sum_i w_{ip} \mathbf{v}_i (\mathbf{x}_i-\mathbf{x}_p)^TBp‚Äã=‚àëi‚Äãwip‚Äãvi‚Äã(xi‚Äã‚àíxp‚Äã)T

      Actually this is Cp=Bp(Dp)‚àí1\mathbf{C}_p = \mathbf{B}_p (\mathbf{D}_p)^{-1}Cp‚Äã=Bp‚Äã(Dp‚Äã)‚àí1 update.

    • vpn+1=‚àëiwipvin+1\mathbf{v}_p^{n+1}=\sum_i w_{ip}\mathbf{v}_i^{n+1}vpn+1‚Äã=‚àëi‚Äãwip‚Äãvin+1‚Äã (Particle velocity update)
    • xpn+1=xpn+Œîtvpn+1\mathbf{x}_p^{n+1}=\mathbf{x}_p^n+\Delta t \mathbf{v}_p^{n+1}xpn+1‚Äã=xpn‚Äã+Œîtvpn+1‚Äã (Particle advection)
Implicit time integration

The main difference from explicit scheme lies in the grid velocity update step.

  • In explicit:
    vin+1=v^in+1+Œîtfi(xin)mi\mathbf{v}_i^{n+1}=\hat\mathbf{v}_i^{n+1}+\Delta t\frac{\mathbf{f} _i(\mathbf{x}_i^n)}{m_i}vin+1‚Äã=v^in+1‚Äã+Œîtmi‚Äãfi‚Äã(xin‚Äã)‚Äã

  • In implicit:
    vin+1=v^in+1+Œîtfi(xin+1)mi\mathbf{v}_i^{n+1}=\hat\mathbf{v}_i^{n+1}+\Delta t\frac{\mathbf{f} _i(\mathbf{x}_i^{n+1})}{m_i}vin+1‚Äã=v^in+1‚Äã+Œîtmi‚Äãfi‚Äã(xin+1‚Äã)‚Äã

    Force is implicitly dependent on grid motion thus the grid velocity cannot be updated directly (backward Euler system).

    With the aid of the equation of motion
    h(vn+1)=Mvn+1‚àíMvn‚àíŒîtfi(xn+Œîtvn+1)=0\mathbf{h}(\mathbf{v}^{n+1})=\mathbf{M}\mathbf{v}^{n+1}-\mathbf{M}\mathbf{v}^n-\Delta t\mathbf{f}_i(\mathbf{x}^n+\Delta t\mathbf{v}^{n+1})=\mathbf{0}h(vn+1)=Mvn+1‚àíMvn‚àíŒîtfi‚Äã(xn+Œîtvn+1)=0

    the updated grid velocity can be computed with Newton-Raphson iteration method
    v(i+1)=v(i)‚àí(‚àÇh‚àÇv(v(i)))‚àí1h(v(i))\mathbf{v}^{(i+1)}=\mathbf{v}^{(i)}-(\frac{\partial\mathbf{h}}{\partial\mathbf{v}}(\mathbf{v}^{(i)}))^{-1}\mathbf{h}(\mathbf{v}^{(i)})v(i+1)=v(i)‚àí(‚àÇv‚àÇh‚Äã(v(i)))‚àí1h(v(i))

    where (i)(i)(i) denotes the iii th iteration step rather than grid node. At each step, Fp\mathbf{F}_pFp‚Äã should also be updated. Usually only one iteration step is taken.

Solving this eqation with NR method is equivalent to minimizing the following objective function:
E(vi)=‚àëi12mi‚à•vi‚àívin‚à•2+e(xin+Œîtvi)E(\mathbf{v}_i)=\sum_i\frac{1}{2}m_i\|\mathbf{v}_i-\mathbf{v}_i^n\|^2+e(\mathbf{x}_i^n+\Delta t \mathbf{v}_i)E(vi‚Äã)=i‚àë‚Äã21‚Äãmi‚Äã‚à•vi‚Äã‚àívin‚Äã‚à•2+e(xin‚Äã+Œîtvi‚Äã)

Transfering the problem to an optimization problem enables a larger time step. This can occur only when the forces can be derived from a potential energy function and the details are omitted here.
