MLS-MPM (Moving Least Squares MPM)

Refer to MLS-MPM for details.
Using MLS shape function in MPM
Easier to implement than traditional MPM since velocity gradient is approximated with affine matrix.
Based on APIC.

ti example mpm88/99/128

iii => grid node, ppp => particle

üëª PIC
  • Particle to grid (P2G)
    • (mv)in+1=‚àëpwipmpvpn(m\mathbf{v})_i^{n+1}=\sum_p w_{ip} m_p \mathbf{v}_p^n(mv)in+1‚Äã=‚àëp‚Äãwip‚Äãmp‚Äãvpn‚Äã
    • min+1=‚àëpmpwipm_i^{n+1}=\sum_p m_p w_{ip}min+1‚Äã=‚àëp‚Äãmp‚Äãwip‚Äã
  • Grid operations
    • vin+1=(mv)in+1min+1\mathbf{v}_i^{n+1}=\frac{(m\mathbf{v})_i^{n+1}}{m_i^{n+1}}vin+1‚Äã=min+1‚Äã(mv)in+1‚Äã‚Äã
  • Grid to particle (G2P)
    • vpn+1=‚àëiwipvin+1\mathbf{v}_p^{n+1}=\sum_i w_{ip}\mathbf{v}_i^{n+1}vpn+1‚Äã=‚àëi‚Äãwip‚Äãvin+1‚Äã
    • xpn+1=xpn+Œîtvpn+1\mathbf{x}_p^{n+1}=\mathbf{x}_p^n+\Delta t \mathbf{v}_p^{n+1}xpn+1‚Äã=xpn‚Äã+Œîtvpn+1‚Äã
üëª APIC


The main difference lies in the fact that in G2P, more information (velocity gradient matrix Cp\boldsymbol{C}_pCp‚Äã) is transfered.
Particle velocity gradient CpC_pCp‚Äã: the formula of it here is based on quadratic B-Spline kernel function. For Cubic or other kernels, the expression is different.

How to derive Cp\mathbf{C}_pCp‚Äã??
Cp=Bp(Dp)‚àí1Dp=‚àëiœâip(xi‚àíxp)(xi‚àíxp)TBp=‚àëiœâipvi(xi‚àíxp)T\begin{aligned} \mathbf{C}_p &= \mathbf{B}_p (\mathbf{D}_p)^{-1}\\ \mathbf{D}_p &= \sum_i \omega_{ip} (\mathbf{x}_i-\mathbf{x}_p)(\mathbf{x}_i-\mathbf{x}_p)^T\\ \mathbf{B}_p &= \sum_i \omega_{ip} \mathbf{v}_i (\mathbf{x}_i-\mathbf{x}_p)^T \end{aligned}Cp‚ÄãDp‚ÄãBp‚Äã‚Äã=Bp‚Äã(Dp‚Äã)‚àí1=i‚àë‚Äãœâip‚Äã(xi‚Äã‚àíxp‚Äã)(xi‚Äã‚àíxp‚Äã)T=i‚àë‚Äãœâip‚Äãvi‚Äã(xi‚Äã‚àíxp‚Äã)T‚Äã

Among these equations, iii represents grid node and ppp represents particle. For quadratic kernel funciton(interpolation stencil), Dp=Œîx24I\mathbf{D}_p=\frac{\Delta x^2}{4}\mathbf{I}Dp‚Äã=4Œîx2‚ÄãI and for cubic, Dp=Œîx23I\mathbf{D}_p=\frac{\Delta x^2}{3}\mathbf{I}Dp‚Äã=3Œîx2‚ÄãI where Œîx\Delta xŒîx is the size of the grid. The detailed derivation is omitted here.

üëª MLS-MPM

In P2G, P(Fpn+1)=‚àÇœà‚àÇF\boldsymbol{P}(\boldsymbol{F}_p^{n+1})=\frac{\partial\boldsymbol{\psi}}{\partial\bold{F}}P(Fpn+1‚Äã)=‚àÇF‚àÇœà‚Äã refers to PK1 stress tensor of the specific constitutive model. For hyperelastic models with a well-defined potential energy density function, this is easy to get.

For MLS-MPM, the main difficulty lies in P2G where Grid momentum is hard to obtain considering constitutive model.

Comparing with traditional MPM, the main contribution is the unification of the affine matrix and velocity gradient. (Cp‚âà‚àávp\mathbf{C}_p \approx \nabla \mathbf{v}_pCp‚Äã‚âà‚àávp‚Äã)

Enforcing boundary conditions (BC) on grid velocity:

  • Sticky: vin+1=0\boldsymbol{v}_i^{n+1}=\boldsymbol{0}vin+1‚Äã=0
  • Slip: vin+1=v^in+1‚àín(nTv^in+1)\boldsymbol{v}_i^{n+1}=\hat\boldsymbol{v}_i^{n+1}-\boldsymbol{n}(\boldsymbol{n}^T\hat\boldsymbol{v}_i^{n+1})vin+1‚Äã=v^in+1‚Äã‚àín(nTv^in+1‚Äã)
  • Separate: vin+1=v^in+1‚àín‚ãÖmin‚Å°(nTv^in+1,0)\boldsymbol{v}_i^{n+1}=\hat\boldsymbol{v}_i^{n+1}-\boldsymbol{n}\cdot\min(\boldsymbol{n}^T\hat\boldsymbol{v}_i^{n+1},0)vin+1‚Äã=v^in+1‚Äã‚àín‚ãÖmin(nTv^in+1‚Äã,0)

For boundary condition enforcement:
For PIC/APIC, when applying BC to a cube moving in x direction, the cube composed of particles will be compressed without moving in y direction.
For MLS-MPM however, the cube will collapse and move in y direction once impeded in x direction. This mainly results from the deformation gradient and constitutive model??

F=RS\mathbf{F}=\mathbf{R}\mathbf{S}F=RS is the polar decomposition of F\mathbf{F}F (R\mathbf{R}R a rotation matrix and S\mathbf{S}S symmetric).
Since F=UŒ£VT=UVTVŒ£VT\mathbf{F}=\mathbf{U}\boldsymbol{\Sigma}\mathbf{V}^T=\mathbf{U}\mathbf{V}^T\mathbf{V}\boldsymbol{\Sigma}\mathbf{V}^TF=UŒ£VT=UVTVŒ£VT, we can simply get R=UVT\mathbf{R}=\mathbf{U}\mathbf{V}^TR=UVT and S=VŒ£VT\mathbf{S}=\mathbf{V}\boldsymbol{\Sigma}\mathbf{V}^TS=VŒ£VT.

For more information, refer to 2016 MPM course given by Jiang etc.

Singular value decomposition (SVD)

Every real matrix Mn√ómM_{n\times m}Mn√óm‚Äã can be decomposed into Mn√óm=Un√ónŒ£n√ómVm√ómTM_{n\times m}=U_{n\times n}\Sigma_{n\times m}V_{m\times m}^TMn√óm‚Äã=Un√ón‚ÄãŒ£n√óm‚ÄãVm√ómT‚Äã
U,V => rotation
Œ£\SigmaŒ£ => streching

Diagonal entries œÉi=Œ£ii\sigma_{i}=\Sigma_{ii}œÉi‚Äã=Œ£ii‚Äã are called singular values.

Dirichlet boundary (Á¨¨‰∏ÄÁ±ªËæπÁïåÊù°‰ª∂): ËæπÁïå‰∏äÂæÖÊ±ÇÂèòÈáèÂÄºÂ∑≤Áü•
Neumann boundary (Á¨¨‰∫åÁ±ªËæπÁïåÊù°‰ª∂/Ëá™ÁÑ∂ËæπÁïåÊù°‰ª∂): ËæπÁïå‰∏äÂæÖÊ±ÇÂèòÈáèÂ§ñÊ≥ïÁ∫øÊñπÂêëÂØºÊï∞Á°ÆÂÆö

Key contribution: MLS-MPM uses MLS shape functions.

Signed distance function (SDF): this function is used to perform inside/outside queries. Different shapes usually have different SDFs.
For the SDF of any point, its sign represents the point‚Äôs relative location and its return value should be the shortest distance between the shape and the given point.

Moving least squares method (MLS)

Refer to LS-WLS-MLS.
To reconstruct a field based on discrete point cloud.

Least squares (LS)

Global approximation. Each sample point is treated equally.

Objective function
min‚Å°f‚àà‚àèmd‚àëi‚à•f(xi)‚àífi‚à•2\min_{f\in\prod^d_m}\sum_i \|f(\mathbf{x}_i)-f_i\|^2f‚àà‚àèmd‚Äãmin‚Äãi‚àë‚Äã‚à•f(xi‚Äã)‚àífi‚Äã‚à•2

where ddd refers to dimension, mmm refers to degree of the polynomial space, xi\mathbf{x}_ixi‚Äã is the sampling points with given function value fif_ifi‚Äã.
f(x)=b(x)Tcf(\mathbf{x})=\mathbf{b}(\mathbf{x})^T\mathbf{c}f(x)=b(x)Tc

The key point is to compute the coefficients vector c\mathbf{c}c.

Weighted least squares (WLS)

Global approximation based on local approximation and weighted summation.

Objective function:
min‚Å°f‚àà‚àèmd‚àëiŒ∏(‚à•xÀâ‚àíxi‚à•)‚à•f(xi)‚àífi‚à•2\min_{f\in\prod^d_m}\sum_i \theta(\|\bar\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}_i\|)\|f(\mathbf{x}_i)-f_i\|^2f‚àà‚àèmd‚Äãmin‚Äãi‚àë‚ÄãŒ∏(‚à•xÀâ‚àíxi‚Äã‚à•)‚à•f(xi‚Äã)‚àífi‚Äã‚à•2

where xÀâ\bar\mathbf{x}xÀâ is a given point, Œ∏(‚à•xÀâ‚àíxi‚à•)\theta(\|\bar\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}_i\|)Œ∏(‚à•xÀâ‚àíxi‚Äã‚à•) is a weight function centered at xÀâ\bar\mathbf{x}xÀâ. The output optimal function is
fxÀâ(x)=b(x‚àíxÀâ)Tc(xÀâ)f_{\bar\mathbf{x}}(\mathbf{x})=\mathbf{b}(\mathbf{x}-\bar\mathbf{x})^T\mathbf{c}(\bar\mathbf{x})fxÀâ‚Äã(x)=b(x‚àíxÀâ)Tc(xÀâ)

This approximates the function at the domain around given point xÀâ\bar\mathbf{x}xÀâ and thus is a local approximation.
For totally nnn sample points with known values, the global approximation can be expressed as
f(x)=‚àëj=1nœÜj(x)fxÀâ(x)=‚àëj=1nœÜj(x)b(x‚àíxÀâj)Tc(xÀâj)f(\mathbf{x}) = \sum_{j=1}^n\varphi_j(\mathbf{x})f_{\bar\mathbf{x}}(\mathbf{x}) = \sum_{j=1}^n\varphi_j(\mathbf{x})\mathbf{b}(\mathbf{x}-\bar\mathbf{x}_j)^T\mathbf{c}(\bar\mathbf{x}_j)f(x)=j=1‚àën‚ÄãœÜj‚Äã(x)fxÀâ‚Äã(x)=j=1‚àën‚ÄãœÜj‚Äã(x)b(x‚àíxÀâj‚Äã)Tc(xÀâj‚Äã)

where œÜj(x)=Œ∏j(x)‚àëk=1nŒ∏k(x)\varphi_j(\mathbf{x})=\frac{\theta_j(\mathbf{x})}{\sum_{k=1}^n\theta_k(\mathbf{x})}œÜj‚Äã(x)=‚àëk=1n‚ÄãŒ∏k‚Äã(x)Œ∏j‚Äã(x)‚Äã is the global weight function which ensures Partition of Unity (PU) ‚àëj=1nœÜj(x)=1\sum_{j=1}^n\varphi_j(\mathbf{x})=1‚àëj=1n‚ÄãœÜj‚Äã(x)=1 at any point x\mathbf{x}x of the global domain Œ©\OmegaŒ©.

Moving least squares (MLS)

Local approximation base on WLS.
The global approximation is not a single function, but a list of local approximation functions based on WLS.

f(x)=fx(x)f(\mathbf{x})=f_\mathbf{x}(\mathbf{x})f(x)=fx‚Äã(x)

For each point x\mathbf{x}x, a local WLS approximation centered at x\mathbf{x}x is implemented to get its function value. As the point moves over the entire domain Œ©\OmegaŒ©, the global approximation is obtained.

CPIC (Compatible PIC)

CPIC is designed to deal with rigid body cutting (Displacement discontinuity) and two-way rigid body coupling. Refer to MLS-MPM for details.
‚ÄúCompatible‚Äù: particle and its surrounding grid node at the same side of the the same rigid body.

  1. Grid-wise colored distance field (CDF)

    Need to capture
    did_idi‚Äã: valid distance between grid node and rigid surface;
    AirA_{ir}Air‚Äã: tag denotes whether there is valid distance between grid and rigid surface (=1: yes; =0: no);
    TirT_{ir}Tir‚Äã: tag denotes which side of the rigid surface the gird is on (= +/-).

  2. Particle-wise colored distance field (based on grid CDF)

    Particle penalty force occurs. (not sure, maybe in step 6)

  3. CPIC P2G transfer

    Only the information of compatible particles is transferred to grid.

  4. Grid operation (apply overall BC)
  5. CPIC G2P transfer

    Need to compute ghost velocity for incompatible grid nodes (impulse from rigid body to particle, projection is needed.)

  6. Rigid body advection

    Impulse from particle to rigid body (Two-way coupling is thus achieved.)

The following is a snapshot of a MLS-MPM program (CPIC) where a block is cut by a thin plane.

üëª Rigid body impulse and penalty force are not considered.


The following is a snapshot of a CPIC program about a rotating fan.

üëª No penalty force is considered thus some particles can penetrate the blades.
Angular momentum theorem is employed to simulate the rigid body rotation with the accumulated impulse from the particles to the closest rigid bodies.


The rotation fan case in MLS-MPM paper.

High performance physical simulation

  • Performance from algorithmic improvement (do less work)
  • Performance from low-level programming (do work faster)

Hardware Architecture

Background

CPU (=> Page Table & TLB) => L1 Cache(32K) => L2 Cache(256K) => L3 Cache(2M) => Pysical Memory
Latency(Âª∂Ëøü)
Each CPU core has its own L1, L2 Cache while shares L3 Cache.
I/O of L1 is faster than L2 and L2 faster than L3.

Locality

  • Spatial locality: try to access spatially neighboring data in main memory
  • Temporal locality: reuse the data as much as you can
  • Shrink the working set, so the data resides in lower-level momory

Cachelines
Caches
CPU Œº\muŒºArch: Float-Point Units
+,-,* is faster than /.

CPU/GPU
